title: When’s the Bus Coming? How to Adjust your Line’s Schedule
content: When’s the Bus Coming? How to Adjust your Line’s ScheduleRemixFollowNov 20, 2015 · 3 min readAt Remix, we know that transit schedules are complicated, so we’ve made a line’s schedule viewable in a straightforward format. Once you’ve learned what one row means, you’ve learned them all!Take a look at this schedule for the 21-Hayes in San Francisco:Our schedule breaks down a service into separate service days: weekday, Saturday, and Sunday. Below is how weekday service looks in Remix. We’ll use this example to walk through what each column means:From, To: These describe the service windows, or the times between which the service is operating. The above example of weekday service shows that the 21-Hayes operates between 5 a.m. and 6:30 a.m.Every: This represents frequency. Here, 21-Hayes is operating every 18 minutes between 5 a.m. and 6:30 a.m. on weekdays.Runtime: This is the estimated transit runtime based on the combined inbound and outbound route length and speed. If the speed increases and the route’s length stays the same, the runtime will go down. If the speed stays the same and the length increases, the runtime will go up.Layover: This represents the time needed at the end of the line for schedule recovery and driver breaks. Layover is a fixed number based on the settings in your Remix map. You can adjust the layover settings to be a percentage of the runtime or a fixed number of minutes. Here, the 21-Hayes’ layover is set at 10 percent of the runtime.Speed: The estimated running speed of the route includes dwell time at stops, but does not include the time when the bus is stopped during layover. Traffic congestion, presence of transit-only lanes or facilities, the number of bus stops, and locations with high dwell time (meaning, lots of passengers) can impact a bus’ speed. Remix does not automatically determine these factors. When we import your agency’s GTFS data, we estimate a line’s speed based on its length and schedule information.Buses: Based on a line’s length, speed, and frequency, Remix estimates the number of buses required. For example, if your runtime is 60 minutes and your frequency is 60 minutes, we estimate one bus. If your run time is 60 minutes, but your frequency is 30 minutes, we estimate two buses.Wiggle: Wiggle is a spot-check for a route’s efficiency: It shows how much time remains before an additional vehicle is needed. Extend the route’s length, lengthen the layover time, or change the frequency, and wiggle will help you gauge the “slack” in your schedule before adding that additional bus. In this example, 7.2 minutes remain before the 21-Hayes will require an additional bus, which would bring the total buses used on that line to 5 buses.Every row in the schedule can be edited to reflect different times of day. If you have a very simple schedule, you can use the “…” button on the right side of any schedule row to add or remove service windows. In the example below, I’ve deleted every service window (including Saturday and Sunday) except between 5 a.m.-6:30 a.m. I can click “…” and “Add service window” to add them back. If you are making numerous schedule edits, keyboard shortcuts exist that can make this process even faster.Now that you know the ins and outs of the line schedule panel, give it a try in Remix.

title: Meet a Planner: Josh Baker of GLTC in Lynchburg, VA
content: Meet a Planner: Josh Baker of GLTC in Lynchburg, VARemixFollowNov 16, 2015 · 4 min readSince his start as an operator in Blacksburg, Virginia, while attending Virginia Tech, Josh Baker has explored nearly every plane of the transportation universe. After college, he matched his business acumen with his belief in public transportation to start Radford, Virginia’s transit system. Now, he’s the general manager of Greater Lynchburg Transit Company, an established system in southern Virginia that can trace its roots back to the city’s horsedrawn carriage network.While overseeing the construction of a new operations and management facility, Josh is also strategizing how to bring GLTC to the next level, which, he tells us, involves “revising our routes, making our structure work better, implementing new technology, making the ridership experience better, improving the frequency of our service, the usability of our fare collection, and upping our focus on our customers.”Transitioning from an operator to a general manager has given Josh exceptional insight on how people use transit. We spoke to him about what it was like to build a system from the ground up and the challenges facing transportation planning in low-density, sprawling cities like Lynchburg.How has having an operations background helped you as a GM?I think this helps me understand what the drivers and maintenance personnel are going through. I understand what it takes to drive a bus and what goes on and how all of this comes together, and that helped me immensely in being able to build the Radford transit system from the ground up. Now I’ve come into GLTC, which is a very old system and has a lot of history, and come into a place where you’ve got a variety of challenges and things going on, and I can look at it from the perspective of a front-line person. Some of the world’s greatest success stories of positive, effective workplaces are companies that take their direction and guidance from their front line, because they know what’s going on.Are there specific instances of your operator knowledge in action?All the time! It comes into play when you think about the factors that cause a bus to be able to run on schedule, or not run on schedule; when you’re trying to sort out what are some trends in what’s going on with your operations and ridership. It gives you the ability have a better idea, beyond a hunch, where to look. For Radford, where I was going around setting up the locations of bus stops and understanding, drawing out on a map exactly where the route would go, I was able to do that in an effective way looking at the area because my intuition and understanding of how people move around and how they need connectivity came into play.The pieces really fell into place and we were in the right place at the right time. You have to be, in situations like this, to be ready to jump when you sense that people are buying in. That buy-in may only last for a year and then it’s gone. If you miss it, you missed it. It’s not going to come back. It excited me and I saw a need and I thought I could make a difference for the community, and I think we did. My reward is getting to see that and getting to see the effects. I can remember for the first year or two driving down the street in Radford: Seeing even one single person standing at one single bus stop was the greatest thing ever. It was the best thing to look at it. When you see that stop and you can say, damn, we put that bus stop there, we hammered the sign into the street, and we put the bus on the road — you’ll always remember that.What’s your ultimate dream for your agency, now that you’re at GLTC?I’d like to see us provide more frequent service throughout the city. I’d like to see us expand our choice riders. I’d like to see us put ourselves at the level that is high enough to attract the attention of those who otherwise might not consider riding our service. I don’t know if there’s a simple solution or a perfect way to get and recruit riders, but we’ll try. Most of the time, it’s economically driven. When gas prices are low and the economy’s doing well, it’s a different story than when people have tight budgets and tight situations to deal with.I personally don’t ride it regularly as a commuter, and I think that in itself is part of why I really want to improve what we do. Like many other choice riders, it’s just not frequent enough for me. I’ll often ride my buses as part of community outreach and to understand what the challenges are, but I wouldn’t be so naive as to claim to be someone who uses my system when I don’t. I think that I personally face the same challenges that many other choice riders face.What do you think about the future of transportation?I think that transit is something that is more heavily demanded by Millennials and Gen X, Gen Y than was by the Baby Boomers. It’s demanded to be more like your New Yorks, Chicagos, and San Franciscos. In order for a city to be viable and marketable to these younger generations, transit needs to be frequent; it needs to be clean; it needs to be accessible, convenient; and it needs to be technology-driven, with payment options like using your cell phone or credit card.I think it’s an industry that has a lot of catching up to do. I don’t know exactly how we’re going to do that, or in what way to convince all entities why transit is so important. Ultimately it’s about connecting all of the generations around a central issue, to provide accessibility and mobility to everybody.

title: Cutting Costs and Increasing Frequency in Greensboro, NC
content: Cutting Costs and Increasing Frequency in Greensboro, NCRemixFollowDec 7, 2015 · 3 min readWhen the Piedmont Authority for Regional Transportation needed to modify Route 9, a nearly four-hour roundtrip route between Lexington and Greensboro, North Carolina, its planners used Remix to cut costs and increase frequency.“We went to Remix, moved the route around, and explored cutting the section from High Point’s edge into Greensboro so we could take people all the way into downtown High Point,” says Kyle Laird, a mobility and systems planner at PART. “With the resulting difference in cost, we were able to increase frequency and make it much more attractive — not only getting the bus to places that people would like to go, but shortening the travel time.”Route 9 was originally planned over a decade ago. Then, the only data available to PART was raw commuter figures and a regional travel demand model that looked at the area within the four metropolitan planning organizations in the region — which didn’t align entirely with PART’s ten-county service area. When Kyle and his team looked at Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics data, they realized they weren’t connecting people from Davidson County to the most desired places. Remix enabled them to add PART’s specific costing information and view adjustments to the line on top of LEHD data, which should radically improve the efficiency and service of Route 9.“Plugging [revenue hour cost] in and moving the lines around was phenomenal for us and allowed us to say, yes, we can increase frequency if we can change the route,” Kyle says. By being able to estimate how much money we should save, we could say, all right, now we can pop in two roundtrips in the morning, two roundtrips in the evening, and one midday and still run it with one bus and two drivers. It really did help us see that it was possible for us to make some novel changes for our system of route analysis and planning.”Changes to Route 9 go into effect on January 11, so PART’s planners have been reaching out to riders to explain the upcoming changes. They’re hearing a groundswell of appreciation.“We got on the buses to talk to folks to tell them what we’re planning and why, and the public seemed to be understanding. No one was angry. The folks who were getting on at that one little stop at the edge of High Point, they were so excited because it would make things easier for them,” Kyle says. “The morning that I was riding it, it was a cold, misty morning and the folks out there, with no shelter, were really happy about the idea of catching the bus downtown at the transit center where there’s shelter and a waiting room. A lot of them had to catch a HiTran bus from somewhere else, go to the downtown transit center, and take another bus to get to the stop we served.”PART is using Remix to evaluate changes to another line, Route 10, with particular emphasis on Remix’s LEHD-based jobs data layer. Recommendations are expected by late spring. “We’ve got this mentality now that’s like, “Hey, let’s really think outside of the box and try all sorts of things to save some time, money, and really try to beef up frequency,” says Kyle, of using Remix for route modifications. “It gives you confidence when you have a tool that provides a good prediction of what should happen, cost-wise.”For more about PART, read our interview with director of planning Mark Kirstner.

title: How Remix Helped Build Puerto Rico’s New Transportation Authority
content: How Remix Helped Build Puerto Rico’s New Transportation AuthorityRemixFollowMar 7, 2016 · 3 min readWhen the Puerto Rico Integrated Transportation Authority — known locally as ATI — was created by Governor Alejandro Garcia Padilla in summer 2014, the island’s transportation paradigm was altered considerably in in terms of both new, different routes and service operations.EFGB Consulting Engineers was contracted by ATI to manage the design, planning, and adoption of the new routes. Its goal was to “reduce impact to the community to the minimum possible” during the agency shakeup, which brought down the number of lines from 37 to 27 overseen by ATI, says engineer Francisco Klein. Francisco and his team used Remix to assess the conditions of existing service prior to ATI’s conception, consider demographic and costing information for the new routes, and compare the two. In addition, the information provided by Remix was used in PRITA’s Title VI compliance report, justifying the changes from the 2013 routes to 2015 routes.We’ve been using Jane as a comparative tool when seeing how the relocation or elimination of former, existing routes looked. What would the impact be on the service and the overall community?Jane, our isochrone, was particularly useful for Francisco’s work. “We’ve been using Jane as a comparative tool when seeing how the relocation or elimination of former, existing routes looked,” he says, “What would the impact be on the service and the overall community?”Viewing Census data in Remix’s layers also helped his team see the social impact — particularly on senior, youth, and car-free populations — of the route changes. In Puerto Rico, taking transit is too often stigmatized as an indicator that you don’t have the ability to own a car, Francisco says. As a result, EFGB has focused on creating “an efficient and reliable system so that people who need it most use it and can say, ‘Yeah, this is working very well, and it’s meeting the goal and expectations,’ and that could eventually translate into more people seeing transit as an alternative.”While ATI is regulating and controlling the new routes planned for the Metropolitan Area of San Juan, the consultants have used Remix to consider systems in other municipalities of the island. Those local services will ultimately work with the systems and routes ATI proposes at an island-wide level. To foster strong and effective service between ATI and the municipal routes, Francisco focused on population data. “We didn’t want to have a system that would be spending too much money and having very limited ridership, so we made sure that we could reach areas with population concentration” in Aguadilla, on Puerto Rico’s north coast, and several municipalities on the southeastern side.I think that, we’ve had it since the beginning, and it’s a perfect combination of integrating things into one single platform. So if you were not using Remix, then you’d have to do it manually“I think that, we’ve had it since the beginning, and it’s a perfect combination of integrating things into one single platform. So if you were not using Remix, then you’d have to do it manually,” says Francisco. “You’d have to basically lay out the routes, and then go looking for the different layers in different systems. So having everything integrated right there, it’s just cost-effective, it’s efficient overall.”While data on ATI’s revamped bus system has yet to be calculated — the new lines were only implemented this past summer — Francisco says that his team “recognize[d] that some of the routes were just too long, and so Remix has been very helpful in assessing that the proposed routes are not as long as they used to be. That way, we think we’re taking one step in the right direction of having a more efficient and reliable system.”Moving forward, EFGB will do ride-check and point-check studies to determine the impact of the new routes. Once the data analysis process has been completed, they plan to continue to use Remix to assess potential route changes based on the collected data.

title: Meet a Planner: Raymond Mui of DASH (Alexandria, VA)
content: Meet a Planner: Raymond Mui of DASH (Alexandria, VA)RemixFollowOct 19, 2015 · 5 min readRaymond Mui is the director of planning and scheduling for DASH, which serves commuters, tourists, and everyone in between in Alexandria, Virginia, an independent city adjacent to Washington, D.C. Ask him what he does, and he’ll rattle off an impressive scope:“Everything from long-range, 20-year long-range planning all the way down to operator scheduling, runcutting, bidding, bid administration, and every step in between. We do long-range planning, we do short-range planning, we do annual budget developments, we do both short-range and long-range service planning and changes, route expansions and improvements, project implementation. We also have a large role in technology implementation and projects, so right now we’re in the middle of the implementation of our automated vehicle location system. We do our routine service and schedule changes, which includes assembling and administering the bidding process. This part of the year, we’re starting on our annual budgeting process for trading out budgets for the next year, our operating budget and our capital budget, which we do every year for a 10-year window. Also, we do a lot of grant work.”Deservedly so, Raymond landed on Mass Transit magazine’s 40 Under 40 list this year. While it’s unclear whether he’s the world’s youngest direct of planning and scheduling, we’re awed by the breadth and depth of his work. We talked to Raymond about the nuances of interagency coordination in the D.C. area and heard from him about what it’s like to revolutionize his agency’s heretofore paper-based planning processes.In what ways are you trying to push more tech, more data, and more innovative processes at DASH?Historically, especially before I came here, the kind of stuff we’ve been doing is very manual, very antiquated, paper-based, old-fashioned. Some of it we still do. A lot of what we do, I want to improve our efficiency in how we do it and the reliability and the comprehensiveness of all of our data. I think that the more or the better that we see and understand our system — and that has everything to do with how we collect our data and what data we have available to us — the more we are better able to improve our system and optimize efficiency, effectiveness, and the user experience. Without having adequate data to do your planning and your scheduling, it’s like trying to drive a car blind. That’s what we’re trying to improve on with the whole function of the department, which is to have an abundance of data available to us to do everything that we do. It’s not that data that we need or that we want, but data that we don’t even realize we can use to our benefit or advantage yet. So that’s one of the things we’re looking forward to with the implementation of the AVL system, APC technology, and Remix.For example, Remix specifically will open up a lot of capabilities to us that we previously have not had available in our department, like the ability to overlay different data sets and be able to determine what percentage of ridership is below the poverty level, or doesn’t have cars, or whatever specific alignment that we are developing a proposal for, as well as streamlining cost development, resource development, resource estimating, and cost estimating. It will help us streamline our process so we can do it in minutes instead of days.You know, what I’ve done, in the past, before Remix, what I’d usually do was take a screenshot of an online map, put it in Paint, and draw the lines on it. That’s how I used to draw my maps. We don’t have ArcGIS, none of that fancy stuff!Where do you think Alexandria will be in the next few years?The city of Alexandria is anticipating a lot of growth in the next 10 years. There are full-blown development plans for both ends of the city, a lot of transit-oriented development and infill development. There are three BRT transitways that we’ll be able to utilize to leverage our system. There’s going to be a big change in the composition of our land use and a big influx of not only residential and mixed-use development, but also commercial development. We’re anticipating a lot of growth and our long-range expansion plan is built out to anticipate all of these developments. We have service improvements built into our long-range expansion plan to accommodate all this growth to get people to use transit before they get in the habit of driving to and from either their residences or places of employment.If you look outside my window right now, I have a direct view of Old Town Alexandria and the Eisenhower East corridor. In addition to federal employers, such as PTO and DOD, moving to Alexandria in recent years, TSA has recently announced the relocation of its headquarters to Alexandria. These are huge employment shifts within the city.What do you think about the future of transportation at large?Transportation, I believe, is an ever-changing industry. It’s always evolving and what’s even more important is people’s perception or transit and what’s seen as the “norm.” The new generations, people are driving much less and they are finding, shifting toward other modes of transportation for commuting or recreational purposes or running errands, we find that a lot of people are moving away from the single-occupancy vehicle, but at the same time there are more options becoming available besides transit and besides the single-occupancy vehicle. There’s the recent introduction of Capital Bikeshare, Uber, Lyft, and similar services around the county.I believe the social perception of preferred transportation is evolving in the favor of alternative transportation and away from the automobile. I see that continuing in the future and it’s shaped recent and near-future development, which have become more transit-oriented, rather than auto-oriented. The majority of future developments, at least in Alexandria, are continuing this trend.

title: Pandora’s Top Spins: ‘I’m The One’ And ‘Despacito’ Remix Come In Hot
content: Pandora’s Top Spins: ‘I’m The One’ And ‘Despacito’ Remix Come In HotEmily BlakeFollowMay 15, 2017 · 3 min readImage Credit: Vevo.On this week’s Pandora Top Spins Chart, there’s the biggest thing in Latin music since “Macarena,” an early contender for Song of the Summer, and a new single from Trendsetter A Boogie Wit Da Hoodie. Read on for more from the chart, and check out the full list here.The LeadersAs Ed Sheeran’s “Shape of You” rides off into the sunset after a 16-week appearance on the chart—eight of those weeks at #1— Bruno Mars’ “What I Like” steps up to #1. While the original version racks up over 6 million spins weekly, the Gucci Mane-featuring remix rises five spots this week, just cracking the top 50.While “despacito” may be Spanish for “slowly,” there’s nothing slow at all about “Despacito (Feat. Justin Bieber),” the remix to Luis Fonsi and Daddy Yankee’s Latin pop hit. The original version has been a sensation of near-“Macarena” proportions, and Bieber’s presence is only making it bigger. This week, “Despacito (Feat. Justin Bieber)” debuts at #2, marking the highest-ever debut on the chart. Meanwhile, the original continues to see a steady rise, jumping three spots this week to #3.Elsewhere in the top 10, Kendrick Lamar’s swaggering “HUMBLE.” rises from #5 to #4, James Arthur’s sweet “Say You Won’t Let Go” jumps back up to #8, and Kodak Black’s “Tunnel Vision” jumps one spot to #10.The NewbiesIt’s almost summer, the season for Samba beats, bubbly BPMs and, naturally, the crowning of the ever-ambiguous Song of the Summer. Whatever Song of the Summer is measured by — sales? streams? product placements? — there’s a pretty good chance that DJ Khaled’s posse cut “I’m The One” will be a contender. Featuring Justin Bieber, Quavo, Chance the Rapper and Lil Wayne, the song is not only steeped in summer-y glee, but is also shaping up to be a top performer on the charts. “I’m the One” debuts this week at #11, but seeing as it’s already racking up close to 6 million weekly spins, expect it to rise fast.After the success of their Salt-N-Pepa-sampling breakout hit “Sex,” LA-based EDM trio Cheat Codes are back with “No Promises,” which features Demi Lovato. The song debuts at #62 this week, six spots ahead of DNCE’s “Kissing Strangers,” featuring Nicki Minaj. Coming in at #80 is Charlie Puth with “Attention” — off his upcoming sophomore album — followed by Brothers Osborne, who make an entrance and a political statement with “It Ain’t My Fault,” at #86.Behind “HUMBLE.” and “DNA,” “ELEMENT.” is among the top-performing tracks off of Kendrick Lamar’s “DAMN.”Debuting at #96 is Kendrick Lamar’s “ELEMENT.,” which is now seeing over 1 million spins weekly. It’s the fifth highest-performing track off DAMN., the Compton rapper’s fourth studio album. And after topping the Trendsetters Chart and making waves with his breakout single “My Sh**,” Bronx rapper A Boogie Wit Da Hoodie returns to the Top Spins Chart this week with “Drowning,” featuring Kodak Black. The artist born Artist Dubose is also seeing more than 50,000 artist station adds weekly on Pandora.The ClimbersAfter taking a twangy turn on Joanne, Lady Gaga’s remedy is apparently dance pop. “The Cure,” which Gaga debuted during her headlining set at Coachella, rises 28 spots this week — from #74 to #46— in its second week on the chart. Also making a big leap is Chris Brown’s “Privacy,” which hits #67 after a few weeks in the 90s.And Russ’ “Losin Control” may be a slow burn, it’s a searing one. While the song’s actually been around since November 2015, it’s seen a nice spike this week — 11 spots — after the release of his official debut album on May 5. Elsewhere, Train’s “Play That Song” jumps 14 spots, Rae Sremmurd’s “Swang” rises 12 spots, and Gucci Mane’s “Both” remix — featuring Drake and Lil Wayne — moves from #86 to #70.

title: Sketching Estimated Stop Locations In Remix
content: Sketching Estimated Stop Locations In RemixRemixFollowSep 29, 2015 · 2 min readStops are a linchpin of Remix maps: Features like Jane are based on them, and they’re used for all our demographic calculations. And because transit service is only available where a vehicle stops, passengers are more invested in stops — where they can get on and get off — than in routes.Remix allows you to automatically add stops every .25 miles. By sketching a line and estimating stops at this distance, you can get a rough idea of a route’s demographics and the accessibility it will enable for your passengers, without needing to immediately finalize stop locations.Estimating stop locations only takes one click. To do so, draw a route. Double-click to finish. At the top of the right panel, click “…,” then click “Estimate stops.”Note that you can’t undo an estimation of stops. If you’d like to estimate stops on a route that already exists, we suggest doing so on a new copy. Estimating stop locations is best used on a new map to provide the base for a rough sketch.Has the ability to automatically add stops to routes made your workflow easier? Tell us about it!

title: Making Remix’s Settings Pane Work for Your Transit System
content: Making Remix’s Settings Pane Work for Your Transit SystemRemixFollowNov 19, 2015 · 3 min readOne of the most useful features of Remix is the ability to quickly cost out new or modified transit lines. There’s no magic that goes into our cost or revenue hour estimates — our modest, yet powerful settings pane allows you to adjust map-level variables that apply to all lines on any given Remix map.Here are the key elements of the settings pane:Costs: Toggle this on and off to display your transit resource need in terms of dollars or revenue hours. Below “estimate costs,” you’ll see three rows where you can input values:Costs per hourCosts per busCosts per mileTypically, Remix customers use an estimated per-hour cost. However, should you have a per-bus or per-mile cost, you can input that information. Remix will take all three factors into consideration. For example, if you know that your service costs $100 per hour and $0.50 per mile to operate, you could adjust the costs pane accordingly.Layover: Here, you can adjust the layover applied to all routes on a map. Choose between a percentage (setting layover as a certain percentage of the runtime) or a fixed number of minutes (added at the end of each end of a trip). Remix will select between the larger of the two on a route-by-route basis.Calendar: The calendar pane describes the time period over which Remix aggregates costs. For example, if a system has lines with weekday, Saturday, and Sunday services, Remix will aggregate the resource need of those lines across 255 weekdays, 55 Saturdays, and 55 Sundays.You can also use the calendar setting to determine specific information about your service. For example, you can set the calendar pane to “1” weekday in order to show a single weekday’s count of revenue hours.Schedule for New Lines: The schedule for new lines pane gives you the ability to set the default schedule for any new route created in Remix.While using the settings pane, don’t forget that your inputs apply to each line on a particular Remix map. To apply different settings to different lines, create them on separate maps.For more information on the settings pane, check out this video or test out different settings in Remix today.

title: Meet a Planner: Mark Kirstner of PART (Greensboro, NC)
content: Meet a Planner: Mark Kirstner of PART (Greensboro, NC)RemixFollowOct 6, 2015 · 5 min read“I just kind of caught that transit bug,” says Mark Kirstner.Mark, AICP, began his career in the Guilford County planning department. He’s now the director of planning for the Piedmont Authority for Regional Transportation, a quasi-governmental agency that services North Carolina’s largely rural, low-density Piedmont Triad (which is home to 1.3 million people and spans 10 counties, plus the cities of Greensboro, Winston-Salem, and High Point). His desire to better unite transportation and land use planning — especially in regions like his, where transit is a lifeline for many residents commuting to jobs in other counties across the region — is front and center when he discusses his work.We spoke with Mark about how his department has begun to gather the kind of data necessary for route planning in the Triad and about how transportation can make places more equitable.Can you talk about what PART is working on and some of the challenges you face in your region?This past October, we started to take a look at all our routes, especially underperforming routes. It’s a recognition that there’s a whole lot more data out there that we can use for analysis. In the past, it was just some raw commuter data, like, 15,000 people are going from this county to the next county. We started developing a methodology late last year because our routes are very unique. They don’t fit the urban fixed-route patterns in terms of frequency, and they’re not circular routes or anything like that. We weren’t finding a lot of information or data in the research world about how if you increase your frequencies — some of ours were four hours, to two hours — what that would mean to ridership.One of the first things we did was a survey of folks using our park-and-rides to see how far they were driving to see if we could get an average. If we drew a 10-minute circle around this lot, how many people would that be? That progressed to using our travel demand model and socioeconomic data to see how many people might be living or working somewhere, then to the LEHD data on jobs and employment. We’ve been refining that since we started down that road. Remix makes that manual process fairly automatic. We had the big super-spreadsheet that our finance department had done about two years ago, which gave us some real insight into each route and what it was costing. That was the basic method as short as a year and a half ago: We pay our contractor this, our fuel costs are this, we put it in Google Earth to get an estimate of how long the route is, then run it and see what happens. Remix really helps with visualization and being able to test out different route scenarios on the fly.How else has technology enabled your work?We started just by looking at what we are calling catchment areas, or geographic zones related to our transit service. We looked at how many people were within a 10-minute drive of the park-and-ride lot and how many people live and worked in a service corridor. We are also using a five-minute walk zones around bus stops and the park-and-ride lots since you can walk up and get on the bus there, too. We use the socioeconomic data in the travel demand model and look at the people and employment in the geographies we create. We even break the employment into job clusters. Then, we started using LEHD data to visualize more people’s movements, or where they worked and where they lived. That, again, helped define some service areas that we had not had before. Now, we’re using our own geographies to analyze the LEHD data.How did connecting land use and transit planning become interesting to you?I worked first in the county planning department doing parks planning, traditional zoning and subdivisions, small-area plans. Due to an odd set of circumstances, I got sent down to the county’s community transportation system, which is the county’s demand-response transit system for medical and senior service trips. I just kind of caught that transit bug and really found it gratifying to go home every day and say we provided trips to 600 people, to get to a medical appointment or a senior center. While planning itself was gratifying, here I could see the results of my work on a daily basis.Having the land-use background when I got to the transit world, I quickly learned that people have to be able to access whatever the transit infrastructure is, and that access is really distance-based, so your land use patterns really impact an individual’s access to transit. You easily see that you’re a low-density area that can’t be truly supportive of transit, but you know that there are great benefits in terms of people saving money; having more compact, walkable urban areas and neighborhoods; and having access to jobs.I’ve been interested in transportation equity lately and I firmly believe that enhanced transit systems can help solve poverty issues. So many things that we do to help people in need don’t really help bring them out of poverty. This goes back to the amount of money that might be needed for a car when you include the total cost. If there’s some way that you can reduce people’s transportation costs by five percent, that’s that much more money in their pocket that provides some long-term stability in terms of more income, food, housing. One thing that cities do is transportation, of which transit is part of. Therefore, that is the best way cities can help with poverty.It took a long time to realize as a land-use planner how little control you do have. I think that here, especially, the market, the development community, and the actual property owners determine so much. Instead of land-use planning, it’s land-use management. When parcels do get developed, is it the best fit for the whole community? There’s that piece of the challenge but, on the flipside, while a city might not be able to totally control where housing or jobs go, it does control its transportation infrastructure, whether highways or public transit. I think cities often spend too much time on other things and not enough on public transit.

title: What Is “Day-to-Day” Planning?
content: What Is “Day-to-Day” Planning?RemixFollowJul 17, 2017 · 3 min readAVTA (Lancaster, CA) accelerates its planning time by exploring scenarios in real time during city council meetings.Planners Are Good JugglersOn a given day, a typical transit planner has many balls in the air. Service planning, public outreach, and liaising with elected officials — these all require a planner’s full attention to keep projects moving forward, and if any are dropped, it could mean a serious compromise for transit service in the community.Here are a few examples of how agencies are using Remix to keep the juggling act of day-to-day planning flowing smoothly.VIA (San Antonio, TX)VIA (San Antonio, TX) uses Remix to calculate more accurate runtimes for detour service.San Antonio takes “Remember the Alamo” seriously. Every year, San Antonians commemorate the famous battle with Fiesta, a 10-day celebration of parades, music, and street markets across the city.But for VIA, San Antonio’s transit agency, Fiesta means that half of the city’s routes need to be modified to ensure ongoing connections for its 150K daily riders.In the past, runtime estimates for detour routes were time-consuming and difficult to calculate, and headways weren’t always dependable. During Fiesta, drivers could never quite tell if they were on time, and riders never knew when the bus would come.With Remix, now VIA can sketch out their modified detour routes and quickly calculate much more accurate headways. With the new detour process in place, buses now come more dependably, and the planning team can enjoy the festivities with the rest of the city!Antelope Valley Transit Authority (Lancaster, CA)AVTA used to get bogged down with “what-if” questions during city council meetings. To answer board members’ questions, the AVTA team usually had to wait to crunch the numbers in the office, only to answer the question at the next meeting — one month later. The bottleneck had real effects on their plans, and the back and forth could add months to a project.Now with Remix, AVTA can explore scenarios during board meetings in real time. The team presents proposals designed in Remix on the screen, and the board can follow along, ask specific questions, and even suggest new alignments — all while seeing how each scenario affects operating costs, vehicle requirements, and demographics served.After one high-profile board meeting, one of AVTA’s planners said, “I can’t imagine ever going back to PowerPoint.”GoCary (Cary, NC)GoCary’s budget department in Cary, NC, used to find it time-consuming to draft high-level budgets for new projects. Worse, line items sometimes seemed unnecessary when taken out of context.With Remix, now the budget department can use visualizations to explain line items in meetings with other teams. They even release the budgets to the public for comment. GoCary says the best part is that budget estimates now only take a single day.For more examples of how to use Remix for day-to-day planning, you can read more customer stories, or just reach out at team@remix.com.

title: What’s New in Remix Scheduling?
content: What’s New in Remix Scheduling?RemixFollowNov 14, 2017 · 3 min readDeadhead runtimes are now editable for each deadhead trip.More Flexibility Means More ControlWe recently shipped four new features to help you customize your experience within Remix Scheduling. Here’s a summary of how these new features give you more control over the schedules you build in Remix.1. Editable Deadhead RuntimesA deadhead is a non-revenue trip that a vehicle takes as part of its fixed route service. Deadheads include pull-ins and pull-outs to/from the garage as well as driving between different locations in the field in between revenue trips.Now you can directly edit these estimates to reflect the time that your agency actually allocates to the deadhead. To do so, simply right-click the deadhead task in the block chart. In the context menu that appears, simply click on the old value and type something new over it.Deadheads with user-entered durations have a gray background.This modifies the deadhead matrix stored in Remix’s backend, so the update will apply to all the other deadheads that have the same start and end location. Note that this won’t update deadheads in the reverse direction, so they need to be edited separately.When a map is copied, the deadhead matrix is copied with it, so all deadhead times will be the same as those in the original map.2. Customizable Block and Run NamesBlock and run names are now fully customizable.Previously, blocks and runs had no identifiers, they simply had a number reflecting their position in the current sort order.This could cause trouble when you wanted to keep track of an individual block or run. Every time you’d sort by a different column, the names would change.Now, block and run IDs stay the same even when they change position in the list, and you can edit them. Now you can have naming schemes for your blocks and runs, helping to keep schedulers and operators on the same page about what work it includes.The names you give blocks and runs show up in the Remix Excel export as well as in the paddles.3. Defining Garage LocationsRemix now allows you to define the location of your garage. To do so, simply right-click on a location on a map and pick “Garage” in the dropdown. Give it a name and then hit “Create.”Remix now allows you to define the location of your garage.Remix still currently only supports a single garage per map.4. Defining Relief PointsRemix now allows you to define the stops where operators can be relieved. To do so, simply right-click on the stop, and click to set “Relief point” to “yes.”Remix now allows you to define the stops where operators can be relieved.Relief points automatically default to “Meal break points”, locations where operators can take breaks after handing over the bus to another operator. To turn this off, set “Meal break point” to “no.”Continuous ImprovementsWe ship improvements for the Remix platform whenever they’re ready, so you always have the most recent version of Remix. To stay up to date on recent changes, you can follow along here, or always feel free to reach out to your customer success manager.

title: From Transit Planning to Tech
content: From Transit Planning to TechRemixFollowJul 29, 2015 · 4 min readA few words from Paul Supawanich, our Director of Customer SuccessThis June, I made a major professional shift from transportation consulting to product. This was a relatively big decision in my life, but it comes grounded in history. Flashback to 2006, despite graduating from a university with “technology” in its name, I decided to take a step in a another and pursue what I thought then to be more of a “brick and mortar” field of study: city planning. At the time, I personally felt an interest to learn more about the ability to influence cities and an element of life that impacts all of us: transportation, with a specific interest in public transportation.Almost everyone spends a significant portion of their life commuting between point A and point B, and I had an interest in making that time healthier, more productive, and more enjoyable. As a transit consultant for six years, I had the opportunity to comprehensively understand the challenges that cities and transit agencies face in their efforts to improve. While there are many elements that influence organizational decision making, there is one in common: The desire for data driven decisions. Yet there continued to be lack of staff-level solutions available to process, analyze and effectively communicate this information, in real-time. Alternatively, decision making for the transit-riding public has largely benefited from real-time arrival data based on GTFS feeds. However, internally, public transportation agencies lack similarly effective tools. I witnessed this weakness across many transit planning characteristics including on-time performance, fare collection, and service planning.Visually uninspiring and unsharable spreadsheets are the backbone of transit service planning exercises across the nation.When I first heard about Remix (at that time Transitmix), I was captivated by its ability to visualize tradeoffs in planning transit. While a simple concept, this is a critically important step in enabling a community understand difficult city decisions in delivering transportation. Furthermore, it provides planners the ability to concisely synthesize some of the most effusive data in transit planning in a matter of seconds. If transit planning is a matter of art and science, Remix is advancing the science saving transit agencies valuable time and resources. These elements excited excited me the most. While the consumer transportation industry has certainly been “disrupted” in the last few years, the same had yet to happen for transit planning. Microsoft Excel, in combination with various spatial software packages continued to ruled the day and I believed there had to be better. Thus, I made the decision to come back to work for a technology start-up whose primary focus is public transit and whose long-term goal is to help plan better transit through software. Through outstanding software, I believe we can have an critically important positive impact for public transportation by putting more powerful tools in the hands of local planners.Within seconds, we’ve imported Albany, NY’s existing route network and immediately evaluate transit alternatives, with cost information and demographic data to visually guide our thought processUnlike many other transit software packages focused on implementation, we wanted to focus our software at the top, the vision. Our software enables further collaboration and experimentation which helps our customers feel confident that they’ve arrived at the best solutions for their plans. Beyond the features and benefits that Remix offers today, it opens the door for a new world of opportunities: powerful software that fits the need and workflow for transit planning and we have only begun. We are currently adding features every week with a primary focus on making our product even better. In our first six months, we’ve gained the trust of over 50 transit agencies around the country who are helping us build the tools to power better transit. I’m excited about whats to come and believe it’s time for transit planning to enjoy the benefits of today’s latest technology. For more on our story, visit us at getremix.com.

title: Better Peak Bus Counts
content: Better Peak Bus CountsRemixFollowJan 26, 2016 · 2 min readAn agency’s peak bus count represents the maximum number of vehicles in service during the busiest time of operation. Often, this is during morning or evening commute periods where most people are traveling to and from work and service levels are highest.Based on customer feedback, we have worked to improve our bus estimation algorithms to more accurately reflect the systemwide peak bus count.Here’s what’s different: In the past, Remix independently determined each route’s peak bus count and then summed those peaks to determine the systemwide total. In the future, Remix will determine the peak number of buses required, systemwide, by time of day.Example: In the diagram below, there are two routes. Route 1 operates in the AM and PM peak only. Route 2 operates the highest level of service midday. The peak of Routes 1 and 2 both are five. The old method determined a peak bus count of 10. However, the new method takes into consideration that the peak bus levels for these two routes are not running at the same time. Thus, the actual peak is 7, which occurs both in the AM an PM service periods.New peak bus counting should be more accurate by taking into consideration bus peaks, by route, by time of day.Next time you login to Remix, you’ll be able to see the peak bus counts at the individual line leveland at the systemwide level (time of the day is represented by the vertical bars). As a result, you may see slightly lower systemwide peak bus counts as compared to before.This new bus counting methodology will rollout on Friday, January 29th. To view, simply roll your cursor over the number of buses, and this information will appear.This is just one of many exciting updates that will be rolling out this spring. Keep checking our blog for additional new features and as always, let us know if you have questions.

title: How to Break Away From the Street Grid
content: How to Break Away From the Street GridRemixFollowSep 24, 2015 · 1 min readWhen drawing a route in Remix, the line will automatically adhere to the most optimal route.Mapzen’s Valhalla, our routing engine, makes this possible. To determine these optimal routes, Valhalla weighs the cost of factors like distance and time. It also rolls in bus access and one-way streets.Sometimes, that results in squiggly lines:These squiggles can be largely smoothed out by dragging the points you’ve placed as stops. But, if you’d like your route to go somewhere off the street grid — into a shopping center to turn around, for instance — you can use our “shift to fly” feature.Simply press shift and continue drawing your route. title: From the Field: Top Trends from the CA Transit Conference
content: From the Field: Top Trends from the CA Transit ConferenceRemixFollowDec 1, 2015 · 5 min readLast week, we had a chance to be part of the California Transit Association’s 50th Conference and Expo in Pasadena, CA. CalTransit is one of two major California-specific transit conferences (the other being CalACT). Foothill Transit (A Remix customer) played local host and provided us an incredible experience in Pasadena (including a trip to the Rose Bowl)There were plenty of interesting topics and sessions. Yet, a key theme heard repeatedly across the three-day event is that technology is going to fundamentally change the industry and we should start preparing for that change. Amen. Based on my time in Pasadena, here’s are my five technology-based takeaways moving the needle in the transit industry.1) Electric Buses Like any transit aficionado, I was eager to walk into the expo to see the lineup of new transit buses with that new car smell. But this year, half of the shiny new 40 footers were not powered by diesel, or even natural gas, but they were electric. Battery-toting, quiet as night, emission-free electric 40' buses.Back in 2010, Foothill Transit was on the bleeding edge of this industry and ventured alone into this space. But today, they’re joined by other agencies in California (Antelope Valley Transportation Authority), and a few others around the country.Battery technology has advanced at a rapid pace, making it more affordable and more reliable than in the past and bus vendors are in an proverbial showdown to try to win over agencies looking to make the switch. With additional options to choose from and more agencies with electric vehicle experience, I think we’ll be seeing many more on the streets in the future.2) Private Ridesourcing It’s nearly impossible to sit in any transit session at any conference without word “Uber” being uttered at least once. The dialogue around ridesourcing companies at CalTransit carried similar tones, but also invoked interesting discussions about the role that public/private partnerships play in transportation service delivery. There still is a notion from many that these companies are competitors. But companies like Lyft are taking the tack that we’re all friends battling a larger opponent of single occupancy vehicle trips.Personally, I imagine a time in the future where public agencies truly could leverage these companies (beyond linking to them in an app) as one of their methods of providing mobility (in addition to other items in the “mobility toolkit” such as buses, bikeshare, and carshare). Some of these options may be operated directly while others are simply a vendor underneath the transit agency’s umbrella.Also, if you’re into this type of thing you might be interested to know that for the very first time, Uber and Lyft are partnering (ala, sharing data) with the National Resource Defense Council and UC Berkeley to produce a study on the environmental impacts of these types of ridesourcing services.3) Microtransit To me, “microtransit” is a word that captures the types of publicly accessible transportation that fall between a 40' bus and a taxi. This could be jitneys, shared-ride vans (Bridj, Chariot), and even shared-ride ridesourcing platforms like UberPool and Lyft Line.I had the opportunity to speak on this topic on Wednesday of the conference. One of the things that stands out to me is the fact there are more new providers in this space in the past two years versus the past twenty. The services that I mention above (any many others) are filling an important niche of transportation between fixed-route transit (low cost, potential longer travel time) and taking a taxi (higher cost, lower travel time), or your own personal vehicle. It’s not just private companies jumping into this space, public transit agencies such as VTA in San Jose, and Cherriots in Salem, OR are getting into the game. Private vendors are supporting public sector agencies by providing the technology foundation for these types of on-demand, publicly dispatched services. (see RideCell, DoubleMap, and Transloc) I think we’ll certainly see more of this to come in the future. For more information on Microtransit, check out this CityLab article.4) Driverless Technology I cringe when I hear people say that driverless cars are going to solve all of our problems. They certainly will solve some but will surely introduce others. I won’t attempt to speculate on all of the topics where driverless cars will make an impact. But we can be certain that transportation habits, vehicle ownership trends, and the built form of our cities will all be affected. The question that remains is when will this change come? During the conference, Tony Seba from Stanford University made a compelling case that historical trends show that game-changing technologies are adopted at a much faster rate than is predicted by even the best experts. Using examples of the adoption of cell phones and even the personal computer provided examples of market saturation far faster than any prediction of the time. Given the way things are going, we very well may expect the same with driverless vehicles and even driverless buses.Maybe the future is already here, driverless buses are slated to be in-service in San Ramon, CA in 2016.5) Better Biking and Walking Infrastructure Ok, so this wasn’t one of the themes from the conference, but I wish it would have been. The conference itself was held in Downtown Pasadena, a remarkably walkable place in LA standards and a place where you can imagine a pleasant walk or bike ride to catch the Metro Gold Line or other transit services. However, from my own experience, I know this sadly is not the case across much of California.Understandably, transit agencies can’t take on all of the responsibility in their jurisdictions for creating safer places to walk and bike (how every transit trip starts and ends). However, they perhaps can place additional pressure on their local jurisdictions for complete streets ordinances, plans, or pilot projects to take action. Places where it’s easier to walk and bike makes it easier to ride transit. Furthermore, when people feel safe and comfortable walking to catch the train or bus, transit agencies may be able to reduce time-consuming deviations or excessive bus stop placement that are sometimes used to compensate for a substandard pedestrian network.Safe walking and and biking isn’t really technologically advanced, but I think this is an important point. Technology has its place as a tool to help us find better solutions, but often, it’s not the solution itself. Sometimes the simple fixes (sidewalks, safe crossings, good multimodal transportation policy) are the best ways to improve transit.For more up-to-date musing from the road, follow me at @tweetsupa.

title: Fifteen modifications later, he threw it into her fantasies — The Warren Ellis Gun Machine remix
content: Fifteen modifications later, he threw it into her fantasies — The Warren Ellis Gun Machine remixRev Dan CattFollowFeb 17, 2017 · 9 min readSo I stripped the DRM off Warren Ellis’s Gun Machine, crunched the text and threw it into the Markov Chain engine. You can see the results here: revdancatt.github.io/CAT782-remixing-ellisAs I already have the code set up pretty well for consuming new text it’s fun to put different things in and see what comes out. I promise I’ll stick the code up on github once I’ve cleaned it up a bit more. In the meantime this is all heading somewhere, kinda.Something I found interesting is that it seems easier to find short snappy tweetable results from Sk1n (that I’ve remixed previously) than Gun Machine. Which of course isn’t a measure of quality, more that Gun Machine’s story whips along at a frenetic pace (and is wonderful) the sentences feel like good solid strongly bonded elements. Meanwhile in Channel Sk1n and other books by Jeff Noon the sentences feel faster but looser, more easily sampled, looped, and remixed.That’s pretty hand wavy, let’s try this instead…It’s a bit like Gun Machine is the melody and bassline, while Channel Sk1n is the samples, synth stabs and one shots. Lord knows what would happen if I threw them together, actually I should probably try that.The idea of using the Markov Chains is to mix things up. A remix of Gun Machine will use just the words written by Ellis and not a single new one. These tiny word atoms also remain in roughly the order Ellis put them in, but sometimes new structures similar in style and tone to the original are formed. My task is to then have a root around the output looking for these small, newly formed gems.I’m a pretty terrible writer and so turn to code to attempt to skirt around that, by using other people’s work and algorithms to somehow generate something new. This approach works when the samplers are talented (i.e. the Beastie Boys) and not so much when they aren’t (i.e. me). It’s like I’m looking for cheats and shortcuts, you never know maybe I’ll learn something in the process.One of these cheats or “inspiration tools” I’ve played with is the N+7 algorithm. You take each noun, find it in the dictionary, look at the 7th noun after that one and replace the first noun with the new one.Here’s an example of a straight up Markov mix from Gun Machine…“Fifteen minutes later, he threw it into her eyes, seemed to take out his phone and answered it with lightning pingback. As I’ve been ordered to conduct this investigation, without a clue that his leanness was turning a blind eye to calculate her alertness.”Here it is again in N+7“Fifteen misapprehensions later, he threw it into her eye-openers, seemed to take out his photocopy and answered it with lilt pingback. As I’ve been ordered to confederacy this invite, without a coach-and-four that his leanness was turnstile a blizzard eye-opener to calculate her alertness.”We’ve stepped out of the Gun Machine world, new words are coming in cross contaminating and building different bonds to the original. I’m not suggesting any of this is new, but it is new for me.N+15 with a small dictionary gives us this:“Fifteen modifications later, he threw it into her fantasies, seemed to take out his pillar and answered it with lightning pingback. As I’ve been ordered to consequence this jail, without a collapse that his leanness was turning a blind fantasy to calculate her alertness.”Novel remixing on the Grid.I’ve been playing a lot with MPC-type sample/beat pads, grids of soft pads that light up and play samples as you hit/tap them… I mean obviously there’s a lot more to it than that and I’m as bad at creating music as I am writing.Music tools are all over the place, word tools though really not so much. I know there are experiments out there — but not many. In my ideal world there’d be more for words, even better my as yet unwritten novel remixing tool would exist, more on that in a moment.The problem with taking a whole novel and shuffling the words around is the narrative gets chopped up too. The characters are still there, Nola Blue, Alice (both of them[1]) and Tallow, but they can easily jump from one scene to the next — wormholes through the pages from front to back, and back again. Time is lost and the narrative confused.But, say I want to make a new novel by remixing from several sources. I take five books, Gun Machine, Channel Sk1n, Automated Alice, Alice in Wonderland and The Big Sleep. Instead of taking all the text and throwing it into a bucket I divide each into roughly equal chapters and just mix those up. More than that though, to create a new Chapter 2, I take all the words from the original Chapter twos [2] and then add the words from the chapters each side of them, one and three. It looks like this……So I’m remixing the originals, but in a more controlled fashion. The narrative of the remix will still kind of follow the narrative of the original books, just. We won’t be throwing something in from the end of one book into the start of another. New characters will get introduced at roughly the same time, and the story will shift gradually from the start to the end.A quick flashback to “The Kibin Magic Kettle Experiment”But I’m still not a writer, so now over to crowd sourcing. Last year I tried an experiment, it was terrible and didn’t work, for reason I’ll get into in a moment.I wanted to see if I could use proofreading sites that promise to fix your copy and so on (although now I think I would try paying someone on Fiverr: I will meticulously proofread and edit 1500 words of English text for $5 which is an option just to see what happens) to play Chinese Whispers on a story.As a quirk of Kibin quickly iterating over business models I snagged a year’s subscriptions worth of proofreading, I could put one article into their system at a time which had a turn around of 24–48 hours. I figured much like photocopying an image and putting that back through the copying machine I could end up with something different after shoving a story through the machine 100 times.I took this story: The Magic Kettle (github) and mangled it up via Google Translate a couple of times — the end result still had the main narrative but the grammar and everything else was pretty shot, but not so much that it no longer made any sense though.I wondered if the story would get restored close to its original source, or if it’d wonder off on tangents and become something else through the process of other people’s proofreading personality and bias. I set myself a couple of quick rules, well one mainly — I’d accept all suggested corrections.The experiment didn’t go well. Not because of the proofreading — the first couple of editors cleaned the story up fairly well, the third took all the life out of it and the fourth put some back in — but rather because the Kibin site made it hard to accept the suggestions. On top of that, I thought GitHub would be a good place to put the results so people would be able to use the tools there to see the differences (diffs) between version.The combination of Kibin usability, GitHub not really doing large blocks of text well[3] and the story obviously just going round in circles after the 4th edit[4] all made me feel that the effort I would have to put in wasn’t going to be worth it.I’d probably do things slightly different if I was going to do it again now.Pulling it all together.I like the idea of “Making Things Fast", however I seem to end up making things slowly — which is why I’ve decided just to say “to hell with it” and write up projects as I go along.I’m going to play with the idea of pulling text into a remixing machine in the same way you can with audio tools. Until I can throw, say, 5 books into the new words-machine, chop them up into chunks and specify which chunks to remix together, much like the diagram I drew above.I’ll then get the computer to generate version after version after version which I’ll review and somehow attempt to pick the “best” bits. See if there’s any hope for the narrative or, you know, anything usable in there at all.If the approach yields useful prose, then maybe I can string it all together and take it to the proofreading site, Mechanical Turk and/or Fiverr. Human machines to force a bit of grammar and structure, and possibly find out if people can spot patterns and make sense of the garbled output. People are supposed to be good at that, right?Then I’ll write about it some more.And probably get it printed and bound, because that makes it real.Footnotes[1] Alice from Alice in Wonderland and Alice from Automated Alice (who is in turn kinda Alice from Wonderland)[2] we actually double up the main chapter to statistically increase the chances of picking words from that chapter, i.e. chapter [1, 2, 2, 3] but we still blend from the previous chapter and into the next.[3] It doesn’t do line breaks very well on plain text, which means it’s pretty much unreadable. But if I put the linebreaks in and a change made a single word roll over to the next line pretty much the whole block of text would count as a “diff”. Good for code that’s supposed to live on short lines, bad for blocks of text.[4] By the 4th edit the original story was back into place, apart from one or two changes that came in right at the 1st edit. I could see that the grammar was going to be shuffled around but it was very unlikely that someone was going to make a change to the storyline. Maybe if I had more patience and stuck it out something weird may have happened but unless I introduced a catalyst for change it seemed unlikely.AfterthoughtsI probably need to mention something about remixing already existing in literature, beyond Pride and Prejudice and Zombies. Taking a character and dropping them into something else is different than taking a sample. A character is some IP that the author can use again and again — you can’t just pick them up and reuse them however you like in quite the same was as a 3 second drum loop.But, people do do this, with fanfic and slash, even to the extent that 50 Shades was a remix of sorts of the Twilight books. But then in the same way that music artist sometimes re-record vocals and samples to avoid coptright, the world of 50 Shades was rewritten away from Twilight. White label vs official release.So while it does happen, it’s different to what I’m trying to do here which is sampling and remixing in the music spirit rather than extending or rewriting a character or creation.Note: This post was 1st published on my own blog on 7th May 2013.

content: Remix-Aufruf fürs UrheberrechtAufstehen gegen die Abmahnindustrie — ein VorschlagDirk von GehlenFollowDec 14, 2013 · 1 min readEin Remix der von Appellen zum Urheberrecht aus dem Jahr 2012 — auf Basis der aktuellen Entwicklungen im Fall Redtube: Es handelt sich um (1) den “Wir sind die Urheber”-Aufruf, um (2) den offenen Brief der 51 Tatort-Autoren und um (3) die Antwort der 51 Hacker vom CCC:Mit Sorge und Unverständnis verfolgen wir als Bürger die Angriffe aus der Abmahnindustrie gegen das Urheberrecht (1) Auch wir sind Urheber (…) Wir sprechen also nicht nur mit Urhebern, wir sind wie alle, die im Netz veröffentlichen selber welche. (3)Die neuen Realitäten des Abmahnwesens sind kein Grund, den Legitimationsverlust des Urheberrechts zu fördern.(1) Bei der Suche nach Schwarzfahrern und Steuerhinterziehern zum Beispiel, müssen sich die Bürger auch einige Einschränkungen ihrer Rechte aber nicht die ständige Angst vor einer bedrohlichen weil undurchsichtigen Abmahnindustrie gefallen lassen (2).Im Gegenteil: Es gilt, das Urheberrecht zu stärken und den heutigen Bedingungen des leichten Abmahnens anzupassen.
