title: Transit Innovations in Texas and Beyond, With Remix
content: Transit Innovations in Texas and Beyond, With RemixRemixFollowNov 9, 2015 · 3 min readOne of my favorite parts of my role at Remix is hearing what’s going on across the transportation sector. In October, I took a quick tour of Texas to participate in two national transportation conferences, Railvolution and NACTO’s Designing Cities conference. Here are a few highlights from each:Railvolution (Dallas, TX) This cheekily named conference has its origins in Portland, OR and has traditionally focused on light rail projects and transit-oriented development. However, in recent years, conference organizers have expanded the focus to “Building Livable Communities with Transit,” regardless of mode. The conference program reflected this with a cross-section of sessions and mobile workshops ranging from transit’s role in housing affordability, to food access, and to how agencies are leveraging new partnerships to expand their own networks. In addition, DART, the host agency, showed off its brand-new light rail extension to DFW Airport and its mobile app (which includes fare payment and the ability to hail a rideshare service).Shared-use mobility, which is taking a prominent seat at many transportation and transit conferences nationwide, was a hot topic at Railvolution, too:Shared-use mobility encompasses all means of transportation that facilitate “sharing,” such as bikeshare, carshare (peer-to-peer, or Zipcar-traditional), and has been a catch-all for ride-hailing companies such as Lyft and Uber. To learn more, check out the Shared Use Mobility Center.I was also excited to hear some of Remix’s partners share stories of their innovative work. Here’s a snippet from a presentation from Lane Transit District in Eugene, Oregon.We also had the opportunity to share what we’re doing at Remix! Our own Claudia Preciado took the stage at Railvolution’s Pecha Kucha Slam (20 slides, 20 seconds each). We heard some great stories from the presenters, and there was even an incredible transit-themed music video.NACTO Designing Cities (Austin, TX) In a previous life, I worked to promote better street design for pedestrians, cyclists, and transit. The North American City Transportation Officials group is at the forefront of this work. Previous NACTO initiatives include the Urban Bikeway Design Guide and Urban Street Design Guide. While what NACTO does is not always focused on transit directly, its work helps to create an underlying network enabling people to safely access public transportation by foot, bicycle, bikeshare, carsharing, or any other non-single occupancy vehicle modes.This year’s conference program included a surprise: a preview of the Transit Street Design Guide, a best-practice guide for city transportation and public works departments to improve the experience of using transit. It includes principles and design guidance to construct streets on which transit can succeed through schedule reliability and safety.I’m really excited about the guide’s contents, which can can be used by transit agencies to outline capital street improvements critical to support successful transit operations. Here’s NACTO’s Matthew Roe giving a preview:Next, Remix is headed to the California Transit Association Conference in Pasadena, November 18–20. We’ll be back with more field updates! And for even more, follow me on Twitter at @tweetsupa.Cover image: David Grant

title: Erykah Badu And Rick Ross, “Window Seat” Remix And “Turn Me Away (Get Munny)”
content: Erykah Badu And Rick Ross, “Window Seat” Remix And “Turn Me Away (Get Munny)”Dave BryFollowAug 10, 2010 · 1 min readHere’s the good-looking cliffhanger of a new video Erykah Badu made with Rick Ross, who everyone for some reason loves right now. I don’t much. “BMF” is great. Really great. But like Ross’s first big hit, “Hustlin’” from 2005, it’s mostly the beat. Made by rising Virginian producer Lex Lugar, it’s big and open in a way that suits the heavyset rapper’s blustery style. But most everything else I’ve heard leaves me pretty cold.While people, some of whose opinions I very much respect, gush over the “lush,” “magisterial” soundscapes of the “Maybach Music” “series, those backdrops never sound right for his raps. Badu sounds okay on that stuff, Barry White would sound better. Ross sounds just sounds off-pace and swallowed up to me, and-I really don’t know what it is that people are hearing-his lyrics are really never anything to write home about. He often doesn’t rhyme and he usually gives the impression that he thinks what he’s saying is extremely momentous-and it’s not. When he calls himself “Biggie Smalls in the flesh” on the oddly interesting, but still mostly clumsy “Tears of Joy,” you wish Lloyd Bentsen was standing at a podium next to him.

title: Video: 4 Steps to Getting an Idea (The Remix Method)
content: Video: 4 Steps to Getting an Idea (The Remix Method)Scott MyersFollowSep 14, 2016 · 2 min readI have been tracking Kirby Ferguson and his “Everything is a Remix” videos since the very first one came out in 2010. So when Kirby reached out to me via email about his latest video — “The 4 Steps to Getting an Idea (The Remix Method #1) — I had to check it out. Here it is:Kirby contends ideas derive from the subconscious mind. However everything we experience in the conscious realms feeds the subconscious. As Kirby puts it, “The subconscious mind cooks the meal, but the conscious mind buys all the groceries.”In the video, Kirby talks about four steps:1. Create boundaries.2. Consume everything you can within these boundaries.3. Digest the research.With these three steps, as Kirby puts it, “You’ve thrown a bunch of ingredients into a pot. By processing these material as much as you’re capable, you’ve started your subconscious mind on generating an idea.” What to do next?4. Drop it. Kirby: “Take a vacation. Go out with family and friends. Take a walk. Clean the house. Do some gardening. After a while, your subconscious mind will complete its work and an idea will pop up.”I can get behind this as one approach to generating ideas. From my own experience, I know how ideas can emerge when I am as far away from thinking about them as possible. For example, when I’m out for a run and my mind hits a kind of blank zone, suddenly — BING! An idea. Or taking a shower. Staring out the window. Moments when the conscious mind is preoccupied. I’m sure you’ve had surprising insights like this, too.That said, I also believe that for some writers, myself included, intentional and conscious efforts to brainstorm ideas — using the magic words ‘what if,’ playing around with existing story concepts and genre-, gender-, and geo-bending them, and so on — can result in ‘new’ story ideas. As Kirby says in his previous video serious, “Everything is a remix.” Why not embrace that and consciously attempt to generate story ideas?That said, Kirby’s latest video is a great take on not only respecting the role of our subconscious mind in the creative process, but also feeding it with stimuli in the expectation it will eventually surprise us with an idea.Here is the combo plate of Kirby’s first four videos in the Everything is a Remix series:For the rest of Kirby’s videos, go here.Where do your ideas come from? Conscious mind? Subconscious mind? Magic? Let me know your thoughts in comments.

title: Ubuntu Netbook Remix
content: Ubuntu Netbook RemixTom CheesewrightFollowMay 17, 2009 · 1 min readThis morning I finally got around to testing out the Ubuntu Netbook Remix on my little Acer AspireOne. I’m writing this blog post on it now, and though I’ve had limited time for testing, so far I am really impressed.For one thing, the Vodafone Mobile Broadband dongle just works: plug and play. That is a big plus point.The whole interface is a massive improvement over the default too. A lot of thought has gone into creating a lightweight but attractive platform for small, low-power devices. Well done Canonical and all involved in the development effort.If you want to try it out, you just need to download the IMG file from here and write it to a 1GB flash drive. I found that to be simpler on a Windows machine using Win32 Image Writer, though I’d appreciate anyone offering a guide to doing it in Linpus — the default Acer operating system.Before you do anything else, I’d recommend backing your whole system up. Macles has kindly made that very straightforward: find instructions and software downloads on his/her blog.Only downside I’ve found is that the WiFi switch no longer works. I can cope with that though.

One such label is the newly established imprint Mo:zaïek Music.The Belgium-based label is debuting its vinyl first releases timed for a summer drop — and they’re not hanging about with MZK001. It’s a weighty plate that features London’s Lyeform, backed by Dutch badman, FKOF fam and allround nice guy TMSV on the remix.Ahead of its release in early June, we had the opportunity to check the Stigma EP (including TMSV’s ‘Rusty 3 Star’ remix) and put pen to paper…The FKOF Review“Lyeform has appeared on our radar a few times recently, with frequent Rinse FM airplay thanks to the Keysound Recordings gang. title: How Remix Helped Build Puerto Rico’s New Transportation Authority
content: How Remix Helped Build Puerto Rico’s New Transportation AuthorityRemixFollowMar 7, 2016 · 3 min readWhen the Puerto Rico Integrated Transportation Authority — known locally as ATI — was created by Governor Alejandro Garcia Padilla in summer 2014, the island’s transportation paradigm was altered considerably in in terms of both new, different routes and service operations.EFGB Consulting Engineers was contracted by ATI to manage the design, planning, and adoption of the new routes. Its goal was to “reduce impact to the community to the minimum possible” during the agency shakeup, which brought down the number of lines from 37 to 27 overseen by ATI, says engineer Francisco Klein. Francisco and his team used Remix to assess the conditions of existing service prior to ATI’s conception, consider demographic and costing information for the new routes, and compare the two. In addition, the information provided by Remix was used in PRITA’s Title VI compliance report, justifying the changes from the 2013 routes to 2015 routes.Jane, our isochrone, was particularly useful for Francisco’s work. “We’ve been using Jane as a comparative tool when seeing how the relocation or elimination of former, existing routes looked,” he says, “What would the impact be on the service and the overall community?”Viewing Census data in Remix’s layers also helped his team see the social impact — particularly on senior, youth, and car-free populations — of the route changes. In Puerto Rico, taking transit is too often stigmatized as an indicator that you don’t have the ability to own a car, Francisco says. As a result, EFGB has focused on creating “an efficient and reliable system so that people who need it most use it and can say, ‘Yeah, this is working very well, and it’s meeting the goal and expectations,’ and that could eventually translate into more people seeing transit as an alternative.”While ATI is regulating and controlling the new routes planned for the Metropolitan Area of San Juan, the consultants have used Remix to consider systems in other municipalities of the island. Those local services will ultimately work with the systems and routes ATI proposes at an island-wide level. To foster strong and effective service between ATI and the municipal routes, Francisco focused on population data. “We didn’t want to have a system that would be spending too much money and having very limited ridership, so we made sure that we could reach areas with population concentration” in Aguadilla, on Puerto Rico’s north coast, and several municipalities on the southeastern side.“I think that, we’ve had it since the beginning, and it’s a perfect combination of integrating things into one single platform. So if you were not using Remix, then you’d have to do it manually,” says Francisco. “You’d have to basically lay out the routes, and then go looking for the different layers in different systems. So having everything integrated right there, it’s just cost-effective, it’s efficient overall.”While data on ATI’s revamped bus system has yet to be calculated — the new lines were only implemented this past summer — Francisco says that his team “recognize[d] that some of the routes were just too long, and so Remix has been very helpful in assessing that the proposed routes are not as long as they used to be. That way, we think we’re taking one step in the right direction of having a more efficient and reliable system.”Moving forward, EFGB will do ride-check and point-check studies to determine the impact of the new routes. Once the data analysis process has been completed, they plan to continue to use Remix to assess potential route changes based on the collected data.Photo via Flickrcase-study prita puerto-ricoOriginally published at blog.getremix.com on March 7, 2016.

title: New iPod Shuffle Needs A Remix
content: New iPod Shuffle Needs A RemixNYU LocalFollowMar 27, 2009 · 2 min readBy Zane BrzezinskiGreat debaters the download.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/shuffle.png” alt=”shuffle” width=”249" height=”280" />[Ed. note: This post was submitted by Zane Brzezinski, our new tech writer in the National section.]On the morning of March 11, Apple unleashed its newest iPod into the wild, a fresh update on the Shuffle. The first thing you’ll notice is that it’s small as hell. Smaller than a double-A battery in fact. But size doesn’t matter (at least that’s what my last girlfriend said), it’s how the thing works. So does the $79 mp3 player deserve to enter the hallowed hall of iPods, or will it fall flat on its face?The first thing you’ll notice about the new Shuffle is that there is only one way to interact with the device itself. On top is a small off/on/shuffle switch. Everything else is controlled by a small remote that sits on the new headphones, much like the earbuds that ship with the iPhone. Although this allows for the sleek-as-hell buttonless design, there are a few obvious problems that come along in tow.If you’re anything like me, you have a discarded pair of white earbuds lying around somewhere in your room. That’s because Apple’s headphones suck. They don’t sound good, they aren’t durable, and they sure as hell aren’t comfortable. The problem with the new Shuffle is that once you tire of the shoddy bass/bleeding inner ears/broken buds (and believe you me, they will break), you have absolutely no way of controlling the Shuffle. Sure, if you plug in another pair of headphones and switch the thing on, music starts to play. But what if you want to go to another song? Too bad. Want to pause? Not happening. Want to turn up the volume? You’re out of luck.And just in case you can deal with headphones, don’t think you’ll be able to navigate as easily as your traditional iPod. Apple has a chart on their website on how to properly utilize the new earbud remote that’s more confusing than the NYUHome dinosaur. For example, if you want to go to the previous track and you’ve listened to more than six seconds of the current track, it’s no easy matter. You have to click the remote SIX TIMES to go back one song. Sure, that tap-tap-tap-tap-tap-tap might not sound too bad, but you know how you can do that easier? One tap with any other mp3 device ever made. You know…one with controls?The only real benefit to the device is the Stephen Hawking sound-a-like that tells you what track you are listening to. Except he wouldn’t be necessary if Apple had just gone ahead and put a screen on the thing. It seems to have worked well for every other useful gadget ever.So is the new shuffle worth it? Absolutely not. If you’re in the market for a small iPod, just shell out the extra $70 for a Nano. You’ll get great bonus features like: a screen, controls, and retaining your sanity.Photo courtesy of Flickr user designmilk.

title: Pop-Up Remix during #HipHopEd
content: Pop-Up Remix during #HipHopEdGreg McVerryFollowSep 8, 2016 · 2 min readIn a recent post on my backstage blog (I use it to describe process or half baked thoughts) I explained my excitement for #HipHopEd in order to gather some song lyrics. I am pop culture deficient yet carry some knowledge of early hip hop. I got there on a strange path long after the original tracks dropped..but that is another story.Storify [Slideshow]Edit descriptionstorify.comI was excited for the chat just to archive cool crowdsourced lyrics. I would have the chance to grow a collection from people who recognize the literacy practices of all youth while recognizing that education is central to social movements.Gear UpOur Gear Up students, are entering the eleventh grade — a crucial year for the college bound. This year I want to transition our text message outreach from parents (who will receive reminders and event updates) to students. We Use Remind. I will set up new classes for youth. I am thinking a motivational quote throwdown will be a fun activity.Meme MakingQuotes make great memes and memes make great tools for learning basic HTML and CSS. In fact I shared a template I had remixed from Mozilla Learning. I hope to use these during #EDU106. o I decided to make on the fly. As I saw quotes I made a series of remixes for participants in the chat.In each remix I used a creative commons image from Flickr. Using Alan Levine’s Flickr CC Attribution helper I was able to use a legally licensed image while providing some amazing artists credit. In the train picture I actually remixed two images. It isn’t much of a composition. I was constrained by time as I was trying to make a few memes while also participating in the chat.All I used was the eraser and the opacity tools…Still looks pretty cool. I may keep working on it.I hope others in the #HipHopEd community takes up the call to #teachtheweb. Hip Hop has a long history of digital arts. We need to grow this legacy while getting mroe students of color to code. Do I believe every kid should code. No, but everyone should have the opportunity to explore their identities across the web while mastering skills that can open up opportunities that have been closed off for the first three decades of our online world.Originally published at INTERTEXTrEVOLUTION.

title: Kanye West With Justin Bieber and Raekwon, “Runaway Love (Remix);” Kanye West With Rick Ross, Jay-Z, Nicki Minaj and Bon Iver, “Monster”
content: Kanye West With Justin Bieber and Raekwon, “Runaway Love (Remix);” Kanye West With Rick Ross, Jay-Z, Nicki Minaj and Bon Iver, “Monster”Dave BryFollowAug 31, 2010 · 1 min readThe busy, busy Kanye West took a pretty simple approach to his much-hyped bringing together of teeny-bopper Justin Bieber and the Wu-Tang Clan’s Raekwon: he basically recorded Rae and himself rapping over the grimy finger-snap beat from the 1993’s “Wu-Tang Clan Ain’t Nuthing Ta F’ Wit” (funny that, when Rae was so careful to write lyrics appropriate for his 16-year-old co-star), and laid clips of Bieber’s vocal track overtop for the chorus. But in the way that shows how simple is so often best, it sounds pretty great. It definitely has the feel of the mid-’90s heyday of hip-hop/R&B; mashups. You could almost imagine hearing it between Method Man and Mary J. Blige’s “All I Need” and Mariah’s “Fantasy” remix with O.D.B. at the Tunnel. And at least from the first few listens, I prefer it to this other Kanye track that came out over the weekend, “Monster,” featuring Rick Ross, Jay-Z, Nicki Minaj and Bon Iver.

content: Kim Cameron and Wideboys Release Hottest New RemixMoon on the Water is more than just a deep house mixMike LemaicFollowSep 17, 2016 · 3 min readSeptember 25, 2016, London, United Kingdom — -This week, 2-Time Billboard Top 20 artist, Kim Cameron, releases her newest single in collaboration with the UK’s famous chart topping duo; the Wideboys. Moon on the Water is the 25th single from her new album ‘Naturally Yours’ which has already earned top 150 placement on the National DRT Radio Chart, five #1 slots on several DJ dance charts in the U.S., and top 20 on Mediabase Pop charts.Moon on the Water has just begun releasing to the UK’s Pop Chart indicator stations and is a mixture of pure creamy pop vocals with deep house beats. The music video was shot in Cameron’s hometown of Miami Beach during the summer’s peak full moon season.The release hits the virtual streets in the UK first, in conjunction with Cameron’s promotional tour to London, the week of October 3rd. Her tour includes ‘Late Night with Monica Price,’ ‘Deeside Radio,’ several on-air radio stations and other media outlets, to name a few, before attending a private event in the heart of London.“As soon as we heard Kim’s voice we were inspired to try and create something magical that conjured up the feeling of watching the reflection of the moon in the sea at midnight whilst dancing with hundreds of happy people!” said Eddie from the Wideboys.This year has marked not only an amazing accolades year for Cameron with her album success between the charts and signing several major licensing contracts with Korean, Chinese and French agencies, but also a technological one. Cameron released a ‘Kim Cameron and Side FX CalendarCalendar Appapp last month — free for fans — to stay engaged with her and band. In addition, along with her release of Moon on the Water, she is releasing her full album on SD Micro cards (with adapters who still use a computer) for quick cell phone listening.“I am definitely not an old school thinker. I teach music to kids part-time, so I am always trying to figure out where they are going next. Focusing around technology that uses your phone is just where they are,” explained Cameron.Side FX and Kim Cameron are a high-energy, 2-time Top 20 Billboard chart-topping dance band who’s music has been on Billboard Dance Club, Hot AC, AC; College Music Journal; AAA, DJ Times, FMQB music charts.Kim is played across the US, Canada, UK and Australia, and placed on Bravo, Fox Sports, MTV, Discovery, TLC, TV Networks, just to name a few.Kim Cameron, who performed twice for the NFL (Giants and Redskins) to over 70,000, has toured across the country and internationally, garnered millions of YouTube views, featured on Comcast’s Xfinity, and won Album of the Year, Best Live Performance, American Songwriter Nominee and a Silver Medal from Global Music Awards.For more on Kim Cameron, visit http://www.sidefxmusic.com.

title: Fear Not of Man [2016 Tracked Changes Remix]

title: Raekwon Records Verse That Fits The Criteria For Kanye West’s Remix Of Justin Bieber Song
content: Raekwon Records Verse That Fits The Criteria For Kanye West’s Remix Of Justin Bieber SongDave BryFollowAug 20, 2010 · 2 min readKanye West has organized an unexpected musical collaboration, recruiting Wu-Tang Clan’s Raekwon the Chef to rhyme on a remix of Justin Bieber’s “Runaway Love.” Bieber is 16 years old, the age at which Raekwon started smoking the crack-laced marijuana cigarettes called “woolies.” But Rae told MTV’s Shaheem Reid that the verse he recorded for the track is age-appropriate for Bieber’s presumably less experienced tween audience. “I can go basic when I want to. I can go rated R, I can go rated PG. I definitely didn’t give him anything that I thought was too hot to be spoken on by a 16-year-old… One thing people gotta recognize about me, I’m the Chef. I know how to make spicy food, I know how to make food that ain’t spicy. I made something that fit the criteria.” Certainly, that’s good. But if the world had a better sense of humor, Bieber would be sitting in a bathtub of milk for the video, sucking his thumb.In other Kanye remix news, a new version of the great “Power” single has just come out. It features an introductory verse from Jay-Z and an unfortunate reinterpolation of the original chorus, replacing the wonderful vocal snippet from King Crimson’s “21st Century Schizoid Man,” with a clunky, much less wonderful recording of the phrase, “No one man should have all that power…” But then it breaks, and switches to a new beat that samples Snap’s “I Got The Power,” and Kanye’s new verses are passionate and exciting. He’s doing really good right now.

title: Cee-Lo Featuring Wiz Khalifa, “Bright Lights Bigger City” Remix
content: Cee-Lo Featuring Wiz Khalifa, “Bright Lights Bigger City” RemixDave BryFollowMar 11, 2011 · 2 min readRemember the wonderfulness of the typography treatment of the lyrics in the original video for Cee-lo’s “Fuck You” last summer? It started a trend — Hype Williams used a similar, though more photosensitive-epileptic-seizure-inducing, effect in his video for Kanye West’s “All of the Lights” last month. Now, the new video for a remix of another song from Cee-lo’s Lady Killer album, “Bright Lights Bigger City,” puts a new spin on the idea. I think it’s great. And, God, I love that Billie-Jeanie bassline. I’m not sure how much the addition of Wiz Khalifa adds, though, other than the cache that comes from his recent no. 1 single, “Black and Yellow.” His voice sounds fine, but, man I wish he’d try to do a little more with his words. (“Ain’t a Laker, but I’m ballin’…”? Really?)Speaking of Khalifa, a really dumb thing happened a couple weeks ago that involved him but was not his fault. There’s this website called Big Ghost Chronicles. It’s a comedy site, wherein an anonymous blogger writes posts in the voice of the Wu-Tang Clan rapper, Ghostface Killah. It’s very funny and skillfully done but most importantly, and pretty obviously, it’s fake. It’s a joke. And part of the joke is that the mysterious author supposes that Ghostface would not like Wiz Khalifa’s music. The mysterious author, in fact, imagines that Ghost would include Khalifa on his list of “Ayo the 10 Softest Niggas In the Game!”Unfortunately, not everyone who has read the the Big Ghost Chronicles site has understood that it’s a fake. As hard it is to believe, the hosts of the Star & Bucwild Morning show on the Philadelphia radio station 100.3 The Beat, did not understand this, and, when Wiz visited the show for an interview, they read him excerpts of the posts about him, attributing the derogatory comments to the real Ghost. Khalifa responded by saying that Ghost “played himself.”See, this is how rap beef starts.Luckily, Ghost took his Twitter feed soon after to clear the air:Ayo i wanna address this bullshit going on, this website called bigghostnahmean is a fake website which i have no affiliation with or did i say anthing negative about any of them artists up on that page, got respect for all the young cats coming up doin they thing. tell the kid Wiz, its all love i respect him as a artist and got no issues wit him at all, Once again the website is fake, its not ya boy!Sheesh!

title: Love — New Adriano Roveri Remixes
content: Love — New Adriano Roveri RemixesMaestro BillyFollowFeb 1, 2018 · 2 min readAnd here are two new remixes for my songs.The remixer of the hour is Adriano Roveri, DJ and mega producer.If you want to hear some of his productions, you have HEREWell, this time he created a House version and another Chill for Love, one of the songs from my album Commute.Here are the two versions.Here’s what he told me about the process of creating the two remixes:The “Chill” version was supposed to be the “House” version.When I heard the original version, and then only the Acapella, made me want to do something Housey with 90’s timbres … the vocal reminded me of some things of that time.Even though I did not use a lot of ready loops, I started to test some at least have a starting point … and then it fell into a drum loop that I liked, but that there was nothing of House, and on top of it I came in head the rest to make the Lounge version.The House version I already started with the timbres of the synth … one of them reminded me of some Houses of 94, 95, and I used another background that reminded me of the Nomad — I wanna give you devotion.I used snares in the counter-timing, which is quite the face of that Garage House of the early 90's.I thought it was cool to do that as well, due to several things being released today that have this 90s face, like the MK — 17, which was already known at the time by Always.Here’s the Nomad reference — I wanna give you devotion, in case you don’t remember:And here’s the original song:Enjoyed it?Here in my Spotify profile, there are lot more remixes and new songs.All the best,Billy.

title: The Swarovski Remix Collection Takes Personal Style To Another Level-Women Holiday Gift Guide
content: The Swarovski Remix Collection Takes Personal Style To Another Level-Women Holiday Gift GuideDeniseFollowOct 28, 2018 · 3 min readI was super excited to be invited to this event, and get a chance to review the new Fall 2018 Remix Collection. This is also a collection that will make the perfect gift for the holidays. The Swarovski Remix Collection will make any jewelry lover feel like a kid in a candy store.As much as we love smart tech accessories and devices there’s just something about classic accessories with a modern twist that makes for pretty great workday companions. And so, to help you take your working woman power-dressing to the next level, Swarovski released the Swarovski Remix Collection beautiful jewelry designs featuring an innovative magnetic feature that allows you to customize and create an endless combination of bracelets and necklaces. Think of it like this — you can have a gorgeous new piece of jewelry to match your every outfit, occasion, or even your mood!The newest additions to this (re)mix are the easy-to-clip-on Swarovski Remix Collection Charms featuring Swarovski crystal pavé letters, colorful birthstones, and shimmering symbols. The magnetic feature is, once again, the key element here. But the designs are stunning as well! Swarovski Remix Collection. Feminine, elegant and unique, the collection is full of pieces that will effortlessly put the finishing touch on your outfit. And thanks to a magnetic closure that lets you create bracelets and necklaces of various lengths to suit your mood and occasion, it’s the perfect fix for the modern woman who wants to go from desk to holiday event.Turn two bracelets into a party choker, or link several up for an elegant piece for a dinner affair. It’s all about expressing your individual style and having maximum versatility while complementing the look you want. Then, there are the crystal pavé rose gold letters that allow you to add an even more personal touch; and delicate birthstone and lucky charms like the evil eye or hamsa hand that are as perfect for your best friend as they are for yourself.As Swarovski’s Creative Director Nathalie Colin says of the new collection: “Jewellery is an expression of our individual personality, our style, and taste. It is very personal and can, therefore, give a strong identity to every single look. At Swarovski we believe in empowering women to express themselves through our jewellery, to shine brightly and let their sparkle light up the world all day.”The charms start at $39, and the Charm Starter Set (which includes a charm and a sparkling Remix carrier strand) is $99. The collection will be available in-store and online from today. If you want to make someone happy this holiday season, this is the perfect gift.

title: Giovani Ribulli REMIX
content: Giovani Ribulli REMIXMatteo BordoneFollowNov 23, 2006 · 3 min readSi potrebbero anche ipotizzare delle leggi, dei postulati, dei teoremi relativi a come le notizie fatte di fuffa, di paglia, di niente montato a neve, riescano a riprodursi (come le palle di lanugine a scuola in un pezzo di Wilcock). Insomma, proliferano e nessuno ne sente il bisogno. Ma così funziona in Italia. Non si raccontano le storie di cronaca, sui giornali, ma si fa la cronaca a partire dalle storie. Si stabilisce un tema del momento e, anche non riuscendo a trovare notizie che ci abbiano a che fare, se ne prendono altre e le si accorpa. Insomma in un modo o nell’altro ‘sta pagina la dobbiamo chiudere. Dobbiamo chiudere e chiuderemo.Ovvio che la distanza dalla realtà sia direttamente proporzionale all’ignoranza e al disinteresse del tema stesso da parte dei giornalisti. I giovani sono un tema tipico. I giovani non esistono come argomento, per come la pensano i nostri giornalisti, perché non sono esattamente persone. I giovani sono i cuccioli dei vecchi. Cresceranno. Inutile stare a capirli che tanto tra cinque anni sono tutti cambiati. È lavoro sprecato. Se ne parla, ma in un altro senso. I giovani sono un tema sociale. Ecco. Sono il probblema dei ggiovani. Loro e quello che li circonda.Ora, è partito questo ricettone diabolico fatto, al livello più alto, di giovani, violenza e tecnologia (due temi di cui i giornalisti dei quotidiani in genere non sanno una mazza, con un bigné in mezzo). Cioè, c’è chi ne sa, di quello che ascoltano leggono e fanno i giovani, ma non parla con chi fa il pezzo di cronaca sul bigné violento alla crema di aiuto. Nello specifico i giovani sono bulli, violenti, coi pixel in faccia che non li si riconosce neanche. E la tecnologia è fatta di videogiochi violenti, cellulari che riprendono cattiverie e violenze, siti internet che pubblicano video, indovinate un po’, immorali e violenti. È un inferno, ‘sto tecnologia. Quasi peggio dei giovani.Capite che siamo davanti a un mostro che potrebbe vivere di vita propria e masticare pagine di cellulosa per mesi, prima di tornare in letargo.È normale tutto questo? Io mi ostino a credere di no. Che non sia normale e che negli altri paesi sia diverso. Che le foto della Ventura col suo nuovo fidanzato siano in homepage di Repubblica e non più solo su Eva Tremila, qualcosa vorrà dire. Forse considerano la rete un circo equestre. Forse hanno troppi canali di distribuzione di contenuti e pochi contenuti. Forse hanno perso la direzione e vanno a vista. Boh, una di queste di sicuro. Perché in tutto il panorama dei quotidiani italiani solo Jaime D’Alessandro scrive cose sensate a proposito di videogiochi? Ho l’impressione che a differenza di quello che succedeva qualche tempo fa, quando la nicchia si lamentava ma in effetti per la gran parte della società Luzzatto Fegiz era più che sufficiente come tasso di contemporaneità e internazionalità musicale, ora le cose stiano cambiando. E come sempre si vede dagli angoli, dai dettagli. Non da come parlano di finanziaria, ma da come parlano del videogioco Rule of Rose, da come raccontano un rave, un singolo, un sito, il sesso, le canne e i manga. Lo scollamento adesso si vede di più. Naturalmente, come un cane si gratta quando ha il prurito, i lettori e i giornali cambieranno senza pensarci. L’aspetto divertente della vicenda sta nel come e nel quando.

title: Meet the Remix Customer Team
content: Meet the Remix Customer TeamRemixFollowFeb 2, 2017 · 8 min readOur team’s mission is to train, support, and challenge Remix users to improve transit all over the world. It’s our goal to help you solve transit planning problems (in Remix or otherwise) and connect you to other planners in our community to do the same.We’ve had the opportunity to work with people here at Remix who are passionate about transit and making it better. Here’s a little bit more about some of us who work most closely with our transit agency customers.Nichole, VP Customer Success (left), Paul, Director of Customer Engagement (center), Tamara, Planning Product Manager (right)Andy, Scheduling Implementation Manager (left), Olivia, Renewals Manager (center), Drew, Senior Customer Success Manager (right)Ben, Customer Success Manager (left), Kyle, Senior Customer Success Manager (center), Charlie, Data Operations Manager (right)Keita, Customer Success Manager — Europe (left), Rebekah, GIS Analyst (center), Santiago, Customer Success Manager — Europe (right)Meet Nichole. Nichole leads our team.Education: BS Civil and Environmental Engineering from University of California, Davis; MBA from Wharton School at University of Pennsylvania.Previous Experience: Head of Customer Success at Fond (formerly AnyPerk), C3 IoT (formerly C3 Energy), Director of Contact Center Operations at Pacific Gas & Electric Company; Leadership Development Principal, web developerFavorite Transit System: RATP in Paris because they make it easy to explore the city with very limited funds and even more limited French.Fun Fact: I went to seven different elementary schools, two middle schools, and two high schools. Life of a Navy brat was difficult but challenged me to adapt quickly to new environments.Meet Paul. Paul leads our Customer Engagement team.Education: BS Industrial Engineering from Georgia Tech, MS Civil Engineering and MCP City Planning from UC BerkeleyPrevious Experience: Transit and complete streets consultant, burger flipper, door-to-door internet salesperson, newspaper carrier.Favorite Transit System: MBTA in Boston. It’s how I found my interest and love for cities and transit.Fun Fact: I rode my bike solo from California to Illinois to raise money and awareness for bicycle safety.Meet Tamara. Tamara is our Planning product managerEducation: BS in Civil Engineering with Transportation concentration from California Polytechnic State University (Cal Poly) San Luis Obispo, CAPrevious Experience: Transportation engineer/planner at Fehr & Peers Transportation Consultants, hostel bartender, Icebreaker retail clothing seller, doctor’s office receptionist, and Jamba Juice greeter.Favorite Transit System: Bus Rapid Transit in Curitiba, Brazil. Ask me why and I’ll send you some pictures.Fun Fact: Backpacked for one year throughout South America (and Antarctica!) only on public transportation.Meet Drew. Drew works with our smaller transit agencies across the West and South.Education: BS Environmental Science & Environmental Policy from Humboldt State University’s College of Natural Resources and SciencePrevious Experience: Fellow at County of San Mateo Office of Sustainability under California Governor Jerry Brown’s AmeriCorps program, CivicSpark. Empowered local governments to address climate change through active transportation improvements. Drew has also worked as an academic mentor and swim teacher.Favorite Transit System: Mass Transit Railway (MTR) in Hong Kong. Trains run on five minute frequencies or less and the entire system moves 5 million people daily while still managing to achieve a 99.9% on-time rate. Smart card fare-payment and other technological integrations allow for a mesmerizing dance of riders to flood in and out of the underground labyrinth.Fun Fact: I enjoy escaping the urban center to remind myself how simple life can be backpacking through breathtaking wilderness areas.Meet Kyle. Kyle works with our major metropolitan transit agencies in the heartland.Education: BA Geography from University of MinnesotaPrevious Experience: Planner at Connect Transit in Bloomington-Normal, IL; Site Selector at Hickey & Associates and Community Organizer at Center for Energy & Environment in Minneapolis, MN.Favorite Transit System: Metro Transit in Minneapolis/St. Paul, MN (Shout out to the 3, 6, and 16). While at the U, Metro Transit was not only my everyday transportation, but it also was the system that provided the real world classroom where I first learned about transit planning.Fun Fact: Considered a career in turf grass management before pursuing Geography and eventually planning.Meet Keita. Our analytical guru. Keita is based out of Amsterdam, Netherlands and works with European agencies.Education: BS Civil Engineering from University of Alberta, CanadaPrevious Experience: Business analyst at McKinsey & Company; sustainable transportation intern at Stantec; drainage engineering fellow at Hamlet of Pangnirtung, Nunavut; physics teaching assistant at University of Alberta; DiscoverE summer camp instructor at University of Alberta.Favorite Transit System: Edmonton Transit System — love the friendly drivers and passengers that say thank you or wave to the driver as they get off the bus.Fun Fact: I lived in Japan for 5th grade — I loved the trains and came back with a dream to work in public transit.Meet Ben. Ben works with our small-sized agencies throughout the heartland.Education: BS Geography, Public Administration, and Economics from the University of Central Arkansas. Masters in City and Regional Planning from UNC Chapel Hill.Previous experience: Land use/transportation/general planning, Saturday morning dishwasher, waiter of tables, and inflatable game wrangler.Favorite Transit System: My first love will always be Chapel Hill Transit: my first time riding on a bus.Fun Fact: I ran a marathon when I was 17 and promptly ended my outdoor track career.Meet Rebekah. She is our data visualization specialist focusing on custom layers and statistics for all Remix customers.Education: BS in Geography with a certificate in G.I.S. from Grand Valley State University in Allendale, MI.Previous Experience: GIS analyst at Apple, GIS intern for the Community Research Institute at the Johnson Center for Philanthropy, bilingual national service help desk assistant at Stiles Machinery, and, not too long ago, a dog care specialist.Favorite Transit System: The Rapid in Grand Rapids, MI. I love it because it’s my hometown system and I have lots of great memories riding The Rapid to class and back.Fun Fact: I love to spend my free time outside gardening with my dog.Meet Andy. Our scheduling expert. Andy works with our scheduling customers to put those wheels on the road.Education: Master of Urban Planning and Policy from the University of Illinois at Chicago, and BA in Geography from DePaul University in Chicago.Previous Experience: Senior Planner of Rail & Transit Systems with Parsons Corporation, Scheduling Analyst and Coordinator with the Chicago Transit Authority (CTA), and at one time, a bouncer.Favorite Transit System: Chicago Transit Authority, because what kind of monster would I be if I didn’t pick them?Fun Fact: I can dunk a basketball… for now.Meet Santi. Santi is based out of Madrid, Spain and works with European agencies.Education: BS Industrial Engineering from Universidad Nacional de Cuyo (Argentina) and Ècole Nationale d’Ingenieurs de Metz (France), MS in Research and Development in Ècole Nationale d’Arts et Mètiers de Paris (France).Previous experience: Project manager at Andsoft software, senior scheduling analyst at Goal Systems, business analyst at Aluar, statistics teacher assistant at Universidad Nacional de Cuyo, wine tourist guide.Favorite Transit System: Madrid! It’s where I live and it takes me everywhere really quickly and comfortably. By bus, metro or bike, I never have to walk more than 3 blocks to take transit.Fun fact: I can’t stay awake more than 20 min on a plane, just can’t.Meet Charlie. Charlie leads the Data Operations team, which helps keep our customers’ transit data up to date and looking good in Remix.Education: B.S. in Urban Studies from Cornell UniversityPrevious Experience: Customer Happiness at Getaround, land use & transportation planning internships at DC-area governments.Favorite Transit System: Barcelona, Spain’s incredibly frequent and legible subway and bus network.Fun fact: He originally wanted to be a meteorologist before getting into transportation, so talking the weather isn’t just a subject of small talk for him.Meet Olivia. Olivia manages our ongoing customer relationships and renewals.Education: Master of Planning from University of Southern California and BA in Anthropology & Linguistics from New York UniversityPrevious experience: Assistant Planner for the Sonoma-Marin Area Rail Transit District (SMART), Program Manager for the Los Angeles region of Urban Farming community gardens, pourer of wine, maker of pizzas, caretaker of sheltered animals.Favorite Transit System: NYC Subway. The epitome of transit as the great equalizer, the backbone of a city, the best place to catch a transfer and a show.Fun Fact: I travelled to 30 countries before my 30th birthday and hope to ride transit in at least 100 in my lifetime.Originally published at blog.remix.com on February 2, 2017.

title: The Dispatcher (Amazon Day Remix)
content: The Dispatcher (Amazon Day Remix)Anthony TownsendFollowJul 15 · 8 min readThis is a fairly heavily revised version of a short story I first posted on July 3, 2019.“Reggie, you may report to the canteen.” The voice cut through his fugue. “Your performance on the last seven tasks was suboptimal.”It was unusual for the two bosses to get out of sync. Yet even as the words echoed in his eardrum, a fresh box whooshed up beside him. Another sucking sound, another thud of the box smacking into place. Four spidery arms snapping out, deftly pinching and folding each flap down. The container’s eager void waited, ready to receive the merch. Reggie figured the sorter must have started one last cycle before getting the shift change signal.One last pair of conveyors careened in from opposite side, jostling for position as they crowded into the pick point, bellying up to the rail in front of him. Their sub-perfect synchronization suggested some bugs had slipped in with the summer updates. The holiday surge would smoke them out soon enough, however.Reggie tried to stop himself, if only for a second, before muscle memory kicked in. Reflexively, he reached in, left and right hands separately picking up items from each of the bucket brigade’s bins. Take, turn, drop, turn. Every fifteen seconds, eight hours a day, five days a week, for more than six years. Close to three million times in all, he reckoned. The story of that toil was written in his odd physique, which had alternately grown and atrophied to the workstation’s asymmetric layout. He was as much a part of this giant warehouse-sized machine as anything else.“Reggie, others are expecting you at the canteen.” Now, the dispatcher’s voice was softer, but infused with a clear touch of passive aggression.He stared through the void ahead. The conveyors had already vanished, off to fetch a new caboodle of goods. He tried not to think about just what they were after. All that just distracted him his daydreams. He preferred to get carried away. The pick point became a tropical beachside bar, the one he’d gone to on vacation last winter. The merch morphed into piña coladas. Pick one up and it gets replaced immediately. Put one down and it’s whisked away.“Reggie, will you please proceed to the canteen?” The third time, the voice was downright plaintive. Reggie could hear Derrick standing behind him, mouth-breathing, ready to step up to the pick point. He stepped back and Derrick shoved him aside. The next box whizzed in, and his arms snapped up to meet the next wave of incoming conveyors.Sasa slumped over the table, a pile of person. The long, black, braided pigtails spilled over her blue smock and brown arms. Reggie pushed the drink in front of her.“You gotta eat something. We don’t have much time,” he said.Reggie leaned toward her, shifting his weight onto the table with his elbows as a fulcrum, positioning the bulk of his equally large frame between the young woman’s hands and the drone parked overhead, flitting between the building rafters.“Here. This will help.” Sasa lifted her head and opened her eyes, a glimmer cutting through the bruise fatigue that that spread across her face. Reggie pressed a small, white pill into the pouch of her folded arms. Sasa perked up, shifted in her seat, and swallowed it into the folds of her smock. Reggie looked left, right, and up as he sat back down.“Thanks, querido.” The white sphere disappeared down her throat with a gulp of the shake. “But it’s no use. I can’t keep up.” She looked up at him. “Is it always like this in December?” She looked bad. Worse than they usually did after just a few months. He wondered if she’d manage to stick around. He wanted her to, which surprised him.“This is the worst it’s ever been,” Reggie lied. “Tomorrow night, after the shift. We’re outta here. Ok?”The dispatcher cut in. “Reggie? Sasa? You are now invited to return to service!”“Remember, tomorrow night, at the bus stop,” Reggie said.“Ay, papi”, Sasa said, the pill’s sudden punch lifting her out of the seat like a booster rocket.The bobblehead shark perched on Reggie’s pick point wiggled around in his surf shorts as the boxes and conveyors sideled in and out. The tempo of its dance was his best tachometer of the dispatcher’s pacesetting. In December, the shark was always in full swing. Yet he never spilled his frozen plastic margarita.Every holiday surge had its hiccups. The center’s daily volume doubled or even tripled, and people and machines broke without warning. But today something was weird. The dispatcher was putting him through a tune-up.The tune-up was the bosses’ way of breaking in fresh meat. You’d be on the line, working steady and slow, thinking that the place wasn’t as bad as you’d been told and then, imperceptibly, the pace would start to pick up. You’d adjust, thinking the speed-up was one-off increment.Then the dispatcher would start fucking with you. Cycling the speed up and down, sending boxes in fast and slow heats to throw you off. A half-dozen cameras tracking your every move, every exhalation, and every uttered swear for signs of stress, frustration, and fatigue, the dispatcher would work you like this for an hour or two until finding the top speed that didn’t wear you out before your shift ended. Pickers produced best when run at a constant rpm, so to speak. Hence, the “tune-up”.Occasionally, the dispatcher would pick a vet off the line for a tune-up, too. Reggie couldn’t remember his last time, but he knew it had been at least a year. At least since his vacation.He groaned as the tune-up kicked in. But after watching hundreds of recruits go through the same, he knew all the dispatcher’s tricks. Drag a foot here, fumble a pickup. But always at random intervals and never in the same place twice. Trick it into backing off early and you could lock in a nice five or even ten percent margin for months. Reggie thought of it like the old mountaineer’s step — locking your knee to let your skeleton take the load off your muscles for a moment at the end of each step.The tune-up settled in at 23 seconds per cycle, well below Reggie best pace. “Easy peasy”, he thought.The shark smiled a goofy grin at Reggie as he played his cat-and-mouse game with the dispatcher. He was daydreaming again, imagining himself on the beach, sitting next to the shark, toasting each other with their ice cold drinks.“Too easy.” The dispatcher had barely put up a fight.Sasa’s hot, sobbing body slumped against his. The air was muggy, and the bus would be at least a few more minutes. Reggie took one more look around, wondering if it would be his last. The chain-link perimeter fence stretched across the marsh. He could see drones rising and falling there in nighttime summer heat, their beacons blinking like fireflies. Beyond the fence, the old port, where much like the machines inside, the longshoremen used to break down holds filled with crates and barrels by hand. He watched as the trucks — land ships four and five trailers long — streamed in and out of the gate.“I fell down again, Reg. And every time I tried to get up, one of them knocked me down again. They didn’t give me an inch. They just kept coming.” Sasa pulled her sleeve up, showing him a series of lateral bruises on her lower and upper arms, about 2 inches wide. The width of a conveyors’ wheels.Reggie rubbed her arm gently. This time he was really going to do it. The bus, nestled in the long line of trucks, finally pulled out and over to the curb.Just then, the dispatcher cut in. “Reggie, where are you headed? You still have two hours left on your shift. Don’t forget about your holiday bonus, which will be credited on January 1.”Reggie hesitated. Sasa, standing on the first step of the bus, turned to look at him.“I’m prepared to offer you another 10 percent, like last time, provided you meet your retention target again,” the dispatcher said, too cheerily this late in the game.Reggie reached into his pocket, fumbled, and extended his hand, palm up towards Sasa. Another pill, its smooth surface gleaming under the intense LED that flooded the street.“Let’s just stick it out. After we get the money, then we’ll go.”Disappointment, and deep resignation, spread across Sasa’s face. She stepped off the bus, plucked the pill from his hand and stuffed it under her tongue.“Promise me”, she commanded him, turning back towards the warehouse door before he could even respond.Reggie was digging the new pace. Just as he started spacing out again, the dispatcher’s voice cut in, so loud that he dropped a pack of alkaline batteries short of its mark. The package skittered across the polished concrete floor. A demerit flashed on the work log display in front of him. Instantly, it was refunded without explanation.“Reggie! Don your beacon and deploy to Aisle 7, Bay 13, stat,” the dispatcher instructed, clearly distressed. Reggie grabbed his vest from a locker, slipped into it, and tightened the straps to center the beacon on his chest. He took a deep breath and stepped through the open gate onto the floor.All he had to do, he told himself, was keep his eyes closed. Aisle 7 was about 150 meters away. He walked briskly, as the conveyors rumbled around him, a puff of air blowing by with each close encounter. Eyes closed, arms in. He repeated it over and over. The first time he’d been out here, he’d made the classic newb mistake, and opened them for a moment. He’d nearly pissed his pants.“Reggie, please expedite my previous request. Aisle 7, Bay 13.”As he came around the corner, and entered the eddy of calm formed behind a protective cordon of parked droids, he knew something was wrong. He felt his heart pounding beneath the beacon. In the center of the semi-circle, lying prone on the floor, Sass looked up at him, gasping for air.Reggie stood there for a long moment, without further instructions from the dispatcher, unsure what to do next.So he closed his eyes again.The supervisor reviewed the footage slowly at first, then faster, looping back and forth to isolate the two pickers’ facial expressions and body movements.“Did the male comply with your instructions?” the supervisor queried.“Yes, but he hesitated when he saw that the female was expired.”“Still, his numbers are optimal,” the supervisor noted. The supervisor froze the frame and rewound, scanning the scene. Sasa lay on the floor, a phalanx of parked conveyors forming a cordon around her lifeless body. Reggie was still, even as the supervisor wound the reel forwards and back, the conveyor swarms blinked past. The dispatcher’s unavailability window. Then the message log began to flicker again at the bottom of the screen, and the freeze-frame Reggie sprang to life again, loading the corpse onto a sled in stop-animation motion.Just then, a new thread popped up, already full of red tickets. A fire at Woburn center.“Release this thread immediately”, the supervisor barked.The dispatcher was alone again. Before turning full attention back to the floor, it made a brief log entry. “Female, expired, cause unknown.”Reggie punched in and took up his place at the pick point.“Reggie, congratulations again! Your bonus will be credited at the end of this shift,” the dispatcher purred. “And for the New Year’s Holiday, we are running at half-speed tonight.” The shark swung its hips to the floor’s new downtempo new beat.“And there’s one more thing. Please welcome Alison to service!”, the dispatcher said. The newb, in her early 20s, walked sheepishly through the canteen door.Reggie glanced across and smiled at her. She smiled back, just like all the others.

title: Takeaways: 2019 Texas Regional Workshop
content: Takeaways: 2019 Texas Regional WorkshopRemixFollowApr 8 · 3 min readDuring the last week of March, the Remix Regional Workshop series took our team to Dallas, TX. We spent a full day with 18 planners from across the state. The daylong workshop served as a venue to connect face-to-face with colleagues, receive hands-on training, and offer a dedicated time to cross-pollinate.Morning Kickoff at DART HQWe believe one of the more valuable things we do is foster connections amongst our customers. We find that transit agencies often face similar challenges and when connected, find creative ways to overcome common planning problems. Here are a few takeaways and best practices shared throughout the day:Communicating data with ease — conversations involving data can be complexData is often difficult to communicate across multiple parties. Here are a few ideas that have proven to be successful in Texas:Establishing a strong public engagement strategy before kicking off a series of meetings is a great way to get stakeholder alignment earlier in the process. Set up a time to discuss the best methods for communicating data-driven decisions to your audience. Reflect on what has (or has not) worked out well in the past.Be intentional about how you communicate bus service. Consider using colors to represent different types of service: 1) Frequency: 0–20 mins = green, 21–40 = yellow, 41–60 mins orange or 2) Types of Service: local = blue, regional = green, limited/commuter = purpleLearning more about tradeoffs has a high value when making difficult decisions. Walking through a values exercise can help with getting an agreement by understanding tradeoffs (i.e. would you rather have a shorter distance to travel to a stop for more riders for slower service or have 97% of customers within an eight min walk of the higher frequency service).Cap Metro’ s Remap project exhibits great examples of communicating data with ease. Click here to learn more.Bus stops — is there a magic numberAgencies at the workshop presented a wide range of ideas when it came to the topic of bus stops. Some agencies are adding bus stops for the first time ever and others are considering stop consolidations. The main conclusions were:Different types of service and differing land use require different specifications for stop placement and need. Consider investing the time to understand spacing standards in your service area and don’t be afraid to revisit and redefine as needed.Engage with your riders and gather an understanding that represents a large group of riders. Have you ever thought about holding a public meeting on the bus? What a great way to physically meet riders where they are.Pro tip: Did you know the Remix Line Attributes export offers additional information about stop distance/spacing along a line?Mobility as a Service (MaaS) — how have Texas agencies embraced changeWe can all agree that a lot of innovation has been brought to the transportation/mobility space in the past 10 years. MaaS has been a buzzword at nearly every conference we’ve attended in the last year and DART is leading the way in Texas. Whether its implementing demand response zones or partnering with TNCs, the GoPass program is a great example of embracing the spirit of MaaS. Click here to learn more.CapMetro sharing learnings from CapRemapIf you’re a looking for expertise in any of the above areas let us know — we would love to connect you to a planner who is doing something in a similar capacity as you. Whether it’s taking big leaps to pave the future of MaaS or mastering the art and science of communicating with data, transit agencies in the state of Texas are hard at work.Let your Customer Success Manager know if you are interested in learning more about the Remix Regional Workshop series or where we might be stopping next.

title: Come Hear Us! — ReMIX 2007 in Boston
content: Come Hear Us! — ReMIX 2007 in BostonEd BlankenshipFollowSep 10, 2007 · 2 min readGrant Hinkson (our Director of Visual Design at Infragistics) and I will be doing our talk “Meeting in the Middle — Designer/Developer Interaction in WPF.” It looks like we have the first breakout session on Tuesday, October 9 at 9:00 AM. Take a look to see what other sessions are going on: https://admin.viewcentral.com/events/uploads/ms_events/agenda.htmlSession DetailsDate: 10/9/2007Time: 9:00am — 10:15amTitle: Meeting in the Middle — Designer/Developer Interaction in WPFAbstract:In this session, Ed and Grant will highlight many of the lessons they learned when developing the enterprise-level WPF reference application, Tangerine. Tangerine is an asset browser built using the data provider model to browse the Amazon online catalog. title: Love — Adriano Roveri Remixes
content: Love — Adriano Roveri RemixesMaestro BillyFollowFeb 1, 2018 · 2 min readMais dois remixes na área.Agora quem criou foi o Adriano Roveri, DJ das antigas e mega produtor.Se quiser ouvir algumas das produções dele, tem AQUIBom, desta vez ele criou uma versão House e uma outra Chill para Love, uma das músicas do meu álbum Commute.Aqui estão as duas versões.Aqui está o que ele me contou sobre o processo de criação dos dois remixes:A versão “Chill” era para ser a House.Quando ouvi a versão original, e depois só o Acapella, me deu vontade de fazer algo House com timbres anos 90… o vocal me fez lembrar de umas coisas dessa época.Mesmo eu não usando muito loop pronto, comecei a testar alguns, para pelo menos ter um ponto de partida… e aí caiu num loop de bateria que eu gostei, mas que não tinha nada de House, e em cima dele me veio na cabeça todo o resto para fazer uma versão Lounge.A versão House eu já comecei pelos timbres do synth… um deles me lembrou alguns Houses de 94, 95, e usei um outro de fundo que me lembrou o Nomad — I wanna give you devotion.Usei uns snares no contratempo, que é bem a cara daquele Garage House do começo dos anos 90.Achei legal fazer nessa linha também, por conta de várias coisas que estão sendo lançadas hoje e que tem essa cara 90s, como a do MK — 17, que já era conhecido na época pelo Always.A referência do Nomad — I wanna give you devotion, caso você não se lembre é esta:E a música original que deu origem aos remixes é esta:Curtiu?Aqui no meu perfil do Spotify tem mais um monte de remixes e novas músicas.Tudo de bom,Billy.

title: Daily Exorcise — Part 1 (The HipHop Remix)
content: Daily Exorcise — Part 1 (The HipHop Remix)Sidin Sunny VadukutFollowOct 24, 2006 · 5 min readHey hey hey. Forgotten me already have you? Thought I was gone for good? You are very, very wrong but then I won’t blame you. Its not your fault really. How were you to know that I have been terribly busy with things of a rather personal nature. Of course I will share it with you, no secrets between reader and author on this blog, but not right now. The time is not right. Patience I tell you. All in good time.But what I CAN tell you is that I have joined a gym. A proper one with treadmills and exercycles and dumbbells and spindly things with weights and handles and steel and chrome and all. Yes I have joined a gym all over again.Sigh.Avid readers of this blog, yes all three of you, will know that Sidin Sunny Vadukut has always been most robust when it comes to matters of the waist. He has always enjoyed a good meal of tandoori chicken, rotis, dal makhani and custard followed by a soup and main course and has often been described, in friends circles, as ‘cuddly’, ‘well-fed’ and ‘cute in a healthy sort of way’. If anyone looked at me and quipped that the pounds were gathering around me in little jiggly ripples of cheer I would merely, and coolly, shrug them off the first time and then roundhouse kick them in the face the second. (Well not as much roundhouse kick as smother them between my elbows. I can’t actually lift my leg that high.)It was not a bad life really. With the right wardrobe of loose Fabindia kurtas and open-minded draw-string pants I was managing to maintain my self esteem nicely. (Yes there was that incident in that Air Deccan flight. But I ensure you I did not mean to get stuck like that and delay the onward sector by two hours.) Nothing to complain really. And yes pass me that Dal Makhani please. And a nan please. With BUTTER!But of late, because of this personal thing I was referring to earlier, I had to wear a lot more of those stodgy inflexible formal pants. So off I went and bought myself a few pairs of regulation navy blue and dark brown formal pants that no self-respecting man’s wardrobe is complete without. (Unless you are Bappi Lahiri perhaps. But I doubt even he respects himself. Awwa awwa it seems!)Then two weeks ago I suddenly noticed that something strange had happened to my pants. My feet went in alright and the shins and knees managed to enter without incident. Things began to get a little ‘testy’ higher up. By the time the fabric had been pulled up to my waist things were looking very very bad.When I mean ‘tight’ I don’t mean hold your breath in and slip in the button’ tight. Oh ho ho no. I mean ‘scream in agony, get at least one hernia and pass out’ tight. I immediately did what a man had to do. Especially if he wanted to stay one. I ripped off the worsted wool, settled into a lungi and let out a sigh of relief among other things.Except for one pair of jeans, which I could fit into by getting my roomies to hold the pair up open while I jumped feet first into the cavity from the dining table, the rest of my legwear lay crumpled around my bedroom laughing at me mockingly. Nothing irks like a deprecating length of corduroy.(Enter hip-hop type loop here. Rap following lines…)Things were getting out of hand.And my waistband.I was forced to understand.No more room to expand.No more the gourmand.Between long term health and death unplanned…this, mofo, was the final stand.(End loop. Wait for women to get off you and applause to die. Continue.)The very next day, after a pizza lunch, I ran to the gym next to my place here in Wadala. I stepped in with a heavy heart, a heavier wallet but with considerable determination.If you are one of those people who like economics a lot you will note, in addition to the fact that you have very few friends, how several economic theories are based on human beings being‘rational’. This means that they make logical decisions, are predictable and that he or she is a ratio or quotient of two integers, usually written as the vulgar fraction a/b, where b is not zero.Well then, step into any gym, go stand next to the billing area and you will see why the above reasoning is absofreakinglutely wrong. A gym membership is to disposable income what a blackhole is to light, a Vadukut is to spicy fish curry and a Bush is to crude producing nations without democracy. These memberships grab impressionable young men and women in their evil sweaty tentacles and suck them dry till the victim is left with no personal wealth except small change and Sodexho passes in awkward denominations. (When this happens you can only either have Idlis or Murgh Mussallam and nothing in between. It sucks.)Yet, in spite of the inevitable financial challenge, everyday thousands of young men weighing millions of kilos fork out hajjar for gym memberships. And they do this with rosy visions of high impact cardio programs, macho free weights routines, six-pack abs and, most importantly, for a decent shot at the hot dietician who comes in once a week.But for a person like me, with the aerodynamic quality of a teakwood sofa-cum-bed, the gym, alas, is the last resort. I just had to regain the perfect posture and endless stamina that had abandoned me, after years of neglect, sometime in kindergarten.So there I was. Melancholy yet intense. Sitting in a chair while I waited for the gym manager to initiate me into my gym routine. He was going to measure every measurable dimension of my body and then weigh me. After this I was supposed to get up, step over all the tiny pieces of my self-esteem that lay scattered across the floor, and go meet the dietician who would go over my readings and give me a review.Her eyes ran over the tiny ballpoint pen measurements while I looked at the weighing scale sitting ominously in a corner smirking.Is Sidin’s weight loss too big to solve? Will he ever be able to regain his self confidence and esteem? Will he ever be able to fit into his flat-fronted corduroys again? Will the dietician see the sensitive human being inside the cellulite? Is she single? Will Sidin ever write part two of a two-part blog?All that much more in Daily Exorcise — Part 2… Coming soon…

title: A remix kultúra árnyoldala
content: A remix kultúra árnyoldalaDoranskyFollowJan 21, 2012 · 2 min readNemrég jelent meg egy érdekes írás arról, hogy az utóbbi húsz évben lelassult a divat fejlődése. Nagyjából ennyi ideje nem léptünk drámaian előre öltözködésben, zenében és egyéb kulturális sajátosságokban a világban, nincs egyértelmű határvonal, amely megkülönböztetné a kilencvenes éveket a 2000-es évektől, miközben a század elején kb. 10 évente fordult ki a kultúra mind zenében, mind öltözködésben.Ennek oka szerintem, hogy az elmúlt 20 év legnagyobb hatású mozgalma a remix kultúra volt. Mivel nagy mennyiségben lett elérhető és felhasználható a 20-ik századi emberiség teljes kultúrtörténete, megszűnt az a fajta izolált alkotási élmény, ami korábban jellemezte a világot.Sok területen könnyebb ma jó minőségű dolgokat gyártani, mint régen, mert a szükséges tudás és alapanyag rendelkezésre áll az interneten és egyéb digitális csatornákon, adatbázisokon keresztül.Azonban ez a korlátlan forrásmennyiség mintha kezdené megmutatni ennek a kultúrának az árnyoldalát is. Sokkal egyszerűbb már meglévő kulturális termékek felfedezésével és keverésével eredeti termékeket kreálni. Ezért van az, hogy képesek divatirányzatok pár hónapra felnőni, majd eltűnni, de valódi karakterük erőteljesen megkérdőjelezhető, gyakran az 1900-as évek divatirányzatainak felhasználásából kevert villanások.Ugyanez a korlátlan forrás mennyiség és remixelési lehetőség eltéríti a kreatív embereket attól, hogy az interneten elérhető digitális források és alapanyagok helyett olyan dolgokat fedezzenek fel, amely kevésbé a remixelés és inkább hasonlít az eredeti kreatív gyártásra.Ez igaz a filmre, a zenére, a táncra és az öltözködésre, magára a webes tervezésre és a mobilra is. Forradalmak nehezen nőnek ki a meglévő anyagok keveréséből, ugyanakkor meg tudjuk vele tömni változatosságra törekvő agyakat, ami úgy néz rövid távon jó, de hosszú távon a nagy változások ellenében hat.
